reviews.title: Interesting 20/30 Min Tour 🙌🏻
reviews.text: In overall it was good, the museum part is good and very informative and the display are great( some scary masks etc 🤪) The people are really proud of the achievements of the traditions over the years etc .. our tour guide was definitely that… Re the Crocs … cool to see but I am a bit skeptical how they stay so still .. medicated maybe … we kinda got rush thru it but we were glad we did as had our kids with us so no chances taken etc .. overall it was good 👍🏻

reviews.title: Not for us at all...
reviews.text: I'm not sure what we missed as this received so many good reviews but we did not like this attraction.  The museum is very informative and worth checking out and that may be why so many people rate this experience high, but the crocodile portion is disturbing.  The crocs are so lethargic they seem to almost not be alive.  I can't imagine how they are so docile... they say it is because they are well fed, but I would think they would have to be way overfed or medicated to lay around as they do. As soon as we entered the "pool" area and saw the crocodiles like that we walked right through and then out of the park.  I understand that animal attractions can harbor a lot of feelings and I entered into this with an open mind but I can't recommend.

reviews.title: beautiful animals
reviews.text: It was a nice experience, the animals are quite tame and I didn't know this species existed so I learned something new again, really nice

reviews.title: Fun and thrilling
reviews.text: Amazing time, our guide Keba was very kind and helpful at getting us to all of our destinations. The pool is run by a nice man who makes sure to do his best without governmental or NGO funding, I highly recommend leaving a donation so they can maintain their work. For a guide give Keba a message on WhatsApp +220 635 8648

reviews.title: A real eye-opener
reviews.text: An excellent experience for the Princely sum on just £1.00, Yes £1.00! and it is not straight in and out, Read all about The Gambia, did you know that Gambians fought on our side in the Second World War?

reviews.title: Worthwhile visit.
reviews.text:
We took a guide/driver. 20 mins from our resort. He explained about the history of the pool.
D100 to get in. Tour of the museum of several small buildings and walk amongst  some monkeys and up close and personal with the Croc's.
They do ask for a donation to "feed" the crocodiles and some locals selling pencils and books for the local children. But on the whole, a good morning without too much hassle.

reviews.title: ''Πολύ καλό''

reviews.title: Very enjoyable visit
reviews.text: What a fantastic couple of hours spent here. We walked from Cape Point (approx 20 minutes) with very little hassle so had the added bonus of seeing where the locals live. It is only D100 per person to enter although when you get to the crocodiles you are asked for a donation for their food. It's all written down in a book so you feel as though it will be used appropriately. The museum is fascinating and worth spending time in each room, although is all written in English so you may want a translation tool if you are not able to read in English. It is worth not rushing to the crocodiles if you love nature and spend some time the other side of the pool as we saw numerous birds including two types of kingfisher. There are also monkeys and rather randomly goats. If you are in the area you should make the visit and from further afield it would be worth negotiating a price with a local taxi driver. We didn't have a guide nor did we feel that we needed one.

reviews.title: Always fascinating
reviews.text: Impressive. I highly recommend a visit to the crocodile pool. Since the sacred crocodiles are only fed fish, you can walk among them with a guide and even touch them. A fantastic experience. And at 100 Dalsi Spot, it's cheap. A must-see!

reviews.title: Crocodiles Up Close, so See You Later Alligator
reviews.text: What a great visit to the crocodile pool today for our group.  Living in Florida, I know to keep a safe distance form alligators.  These scared crocodiles are mostly tame, IF you follow the guide's exact instructions! We observed their mostly laidback behavior with a few movements and a few yawns.  Under the guide's direction we were able to touch the albino alligator.

reviews.title: Highly recommended
reviews.text: Ali_tours_gambia: This is the Instagram account of a local who takes you on an adventure. Ali is a very friendly man. This is his WhatsApp number: +220 771 1288. Highly recommended. The park itself isn't very big, but you do see a lot of crocodiles. You can pet their tails and take a picture. There are plenty of guides who will tell you what you can and can't do.

reviews.title: Excellent.
reviews.text: Up close with some monkeys and up close with the crocodiles.   You can touch the crocodiles.  The price of entrance is less than 2 dollars.   There is a small museum in the park as well.   What more could you ask for?

reviews.title: Nice to have seen it
reviews.text: Incredibly small. Crocodiles lie there as if stunned. After a visit to Monkey Park, this is nothing special. It was nice to see it briefly.

reviews.title: Very Good Trip! 100% Must See
reviews.text: We called in here on the way back to our hotel and it was definitely worth it! D100 entry fee was reasonable and they may ask for a donation at the end which is completely up to you if you want to give some. The crocodiles let you close to them and touch without them moving at all. The pool guides are knowledgeable and friendly

reviews.title: It was a fantastic experience

reviews.title: The crocodiles are not fake they are real. They give them lots of food, and you are allowed to touch them take pictures

reviews.title: 冈比亚小鳄鱼园
reviews.text: 非常小的一个收费公园，游客不多，有一些猴子，鸟类和蜥蜴。鳄鱼比较小，工作人员比较友好。作为医疗队一名成员来冈比亚进行医疗援助，周末来驻地附近游玩。

reviews.title: Not big but special
reviews.text: It's not a large park, so don't expect too much. Nevertheless, it was a unique experience. Our taxi also served as our guide and gave us a passionate tour.

reviews.title: GREAT EXPERIENCE
reviews.text: So, here we are, in the heart of Bakau, Gambia, and we have come to discover the famous Kachikally Crocodile Pool. It is incredibly fascinating. Imagine, a 9-acre site with a sacred pool, an ethnographic museum, a mini forest trail, and even a nearby refreshment bar. It's like entering another world. From the moment we arrive, we are immersed in this mystical atmosphere. Local Gambians told us that this place is renowned for its healing powers. People come here to seek blessings, and some infertile women even come to pray to conceive. It's impressive to see how important this place is to the local community. While exploring the pool, we were amazed to see about 80 crocodiles, some dozing on the banks. And the most amazing thing is that we are allowed to touch them! So why not? After our previous experience with the lions, nothing can stop us! These reptiles are fed exclusively fish twice a week, and despite their proximity to the salt marshes, the pool water remains fresh and inviting. However, not really wanting to dive among them, we simply approach from behind and touch them. The skin is less thick than I imagined, the scales remain flexible. To make the crocodile move forward, you have to press quite hard on the base of the tail. The history and legends surrounding this place are just as captivating. We were told how the pool sanctuary was revealed to the Mandingo Bojang family more than 520 years ago. Another story speaks of a supernatural entity, a female Djinn, who lost her child here, thus giving birth to the sanctification of the well. And the Kachikally Museum is simply remarkable. With its 1,000 historical artifacts displayed in four round African huts, it immerses us even deeper into the history of Bakau and the many ethnic groups of The Gambia. It's like a journey back in time, a total immersion in the local culture and traditions. Ultimately, our discovery of the Kachikally Crocodile Pool and its museum will remain etched in our memories as an unforgettable experience. It is truly a rare pearl, a treasure of The Gambia that we are grateful to have had the opportunity to discover. VOYAGEAVECNOUS.COM FB AND INSTA AUTOURDOMONDE2023

reviews.title: Fantastic
reviews.text: Visted around 11am and it seems to be a good time to go. Not busy or rushed. Guide was knowledge and good fun. A wonderful opportunity to find out and get up close to these fascinating animals. They are well cared for and happy to tolerate humans as they are well fed. Do listen to the guide as some pregnant crops will not be so happy to be approached. Great local information in series of rooms on the way in about tribes, musical instruments, and info about military history. Entrance fee 100 D and an opportunity to leave a contribution to help towards food for the crops.

reviews.title: Short but sweet 🐊
reviews.text: Very small, you can get through it in no time. Entrance 100D (about 1.36 €) You enter a very small museum, which has nothing to do with crocodiles. But it is interesting. After that it is a bit of a walk and you are among the crocodiles. They are very calm. Some seemed like living statues. You can touch them, they don't react to that (so no bother) The crocodiles are said to be so calm because they get a lot of food and therefore don't have to hunt (a crocodile can go days without food) so they lie there to digest. The crocodiles are also said to be vegetarian🤣 There is a book at the end where you can write your name and make a contribution. Thank you kindly. Don't expect too much.

reviews.title: Croc Pool
reviews.text: Informative little museum about the different tribes and history of The Gambia. Wonderful experience to stand amongst the crocodiles!

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text: Unbelievable experience,  we get to touch the crocodiles and the staff was very helpful and informative.  Fee entrance is only 100 dalasi which is nothing so we donate some money as well

reviews.title: Amazing experience
reviews.text: Different experience, touching crocodiles. We went with a local guide Lamin Marong, who picked us up from hotel , drove to the pool, guided us through the museum and then to the pool, where a keeper told us which ones we could touch, then Lamin drove us back, with a brief visit to a war graves cemetery, all for £20

reviews.title: Crocs, crocs and more crocs
reviews.text:
Never seen so many! The more you look, the more you see. Very knowledgeable guides ensure your visit is safe. There are some cross you can actually touch
Also a very interesting museum about Gambias recent history is on the same site.

reviews.title: Go see the crocodile
reviews.text:
Lovely place  But make no mistake these listen to your guide if you want to touch them I did and must admit my heart was racing 
But well worth going to see them up close

reviews.title: Don't Shed Tears for These Crocodiles
reviews.text: Over a dozen crocodiles laying al around the pool, mostly sleeping.  You get to walk a path with your guide around the place when suddenly you notice there is no fence between you and those crocodiles about 4 feet away.  Luckily, only a few are moving and you are really glad they were fed earlier in the day.  I would question your fitness as a parent if you brought your kiddos on your visit.  Just remember if you want to touch one (and people do) touch the crocodile as far away from its mouth as possible.  If you love Komodo Island and its free roaming dragons you will like this place.

reviews.title: Nice to see once but it doesn't amount to much!
reviews.text: We booked a bike tour, and this was one of the stops. First, you enter a small museum that's also part of the park. Our guide gave the woman at the door some money, so I don't know the entrance fee. Here, you see a bit of Gambian history through photos with English explanations and African masks. It's not much, to be honest. You quickly walk out the back to the crocodiles. It's fun to see them. There are a lot of them; around 100 are said to live there. We understand it's also a kind of sanctuary. There are also many "handlers" there. They are friendly and will help take nice pictures of you and the crocodiles if you like. You can also touch one crocodile (the albino one) for photos if you like. There's no charge for this. The crocodiles are everywhere (especially in the pond, which is covered in leaves, so you don't see them), and you simply walk around them. They tell you where to walk to stay safe. After about 20 minutes, you've seen it all. Afterward, you're asked for a small donation to buy fish for the crocodiles. They also display a table with supplies (markers, coloring books, etc.). They try to get you to buy these for the children you'll see in Gambia. You can then share them. We didn't do this, but we did donate some money for the fish and the effort they made to take nice pictures of us.

reviews.title: à voir
reviews.text:
very interesting site, apparently in activity since centuries. 
There is a little interesting museum, a  park and LOTS of crocodiles.
You may even touch some of them. 
The explanations given by the guide on how the keep the crocodiles number under control were not convincing at all, so we remain with the question.

reviews.title: Interesting and fun
reviews.text:
Never believed I could be comfortable walking amongst a bunch of very large crocodiles, and even petting one, but I was. There is an interesting history to this place. The owner has fed the crocs only fish for their entire lives, and they have been acclimated to people, so as long as you follow their instructions to move slowly and ONLY pet their backs, you are safe.

Makes for a great photo op! And the museum outside is definitely worth a stop.

reviews.title: Awesome Experience
reviews.text: This must see site was in walking distance from.our hotel,but it did mean a walk through Bakau old town which is a poverty striking area with lots of kids begging for sweets, so I was glad we hired a guy from the beach to take us there, as his presence made the journey there very easy. The entrance fee is only 100 DL (just over £1) and there is an interesting museum about the history of Gambia to go through before one hits the jungle trail. There is a well trodden path, through some huge trees and local monkeys until you hit the pool, where rangers will arrange for visitors to pose with and touch the crocs for some great photo opportunities. These are fresh water crocs and are fish eaters, and well fed. So humans are quite safe, but even ard visitors are told to keep well away from the crocs mouths in case you confuse the crocs and they take a bite. If you are lucky on your visit you may get to see Charlie the albino Croc. A good and cheap way to spend a couple of hours.

reviews.title: Crocodile
reviews.text: Mixed feelings because I don't like animal exploitation, but I've been told the animals and their offspring are well cared for. It's a special experience to walk among the crocodiles and touch them.

reviews.title: Fantastic experience
reviews.text: This was my 2nd visit to Katchikally Crocodile Pool once again it was a remarkable wondrous experience. We went quite late in the day plus it was Ramadan time so it was very quiet. We were the only people there. There was a 200 deductions entrance fee. Before going to see the crocodiles there is a small museum we walked around which consisted of 3 rooms with information about the area , pictures and a few historical artifacts. The whole way round we were accompanied by a cat. He literally walked everywhere with us until we got to the exit of the rooms. Instinctively the cat stopped at the door and left us to continue out towards the crocodiles. She obviously didn't know to go out there around the crocodiles, we stopped at a very far old massive cotton tree on the way towards the crocodiles. The young man who cared for the crocodiles were so informative and put us at ease as when we got out towards the crocodiles. On this occasion, there were plenty of them out on the land. We counted at least 12 crocodiles among leaves and against the trees. This was a scarily wonderful experience to be this close to the crocodiles, we even saw the albino crocodile which was so big. The young man showed us the crocodile eggs and told us about the crocodiles. We made a small donation towards feeding the crocodiles as they must go through a large amount of fish to keep them going. This was a fantastic experience. Definitely not for the faint hearted.

reviews.title: Pool of Crocs
reviews.text: Located about 30 minutes from Banjul, in the Bakau district, the Kachikally Sacred Crocodile Pool is believed by the locals for its healing powers and as a place of last resort for infertile women who wish to conceive. the women seeking the special blessing are washed by trained women and are told not to shake hands with anyone in Bakau. Others with ailments come to the pool to seek luck and make offerings to the crocs in return. The walk to the pool is reached from the mail road by a 600-meter dirt pathway that is lined by poverty-stricken housing and dozens of young children approaching you asking for money or school supplies. The entrance wall is colorfully painted with wildlife scenes. Once inside, you walk on a path towards the pool where it is said that there are over 80 crocodiles in and around the pool but we only saw four small crocks. The well-fed crocs are docile. Visitors are allowed to touch or stroke the tail--not the head. Expect to spend about 30 minutes in the facility. Other than the few crocs there is not much to see. Worth a visit if you are in the area but otherwise not much to see although it is described as a popular tourist site. At the end of the tour the owner requests "donations" to feed the crocs.

reviews.title: Superrrr
reviews.text: We had a wonderful time at the crocodile pool in Gambia! I really recommend people to get a local guide: much more personal attention, you support the locals and you're not stuck in a van with 60 other people, haha. A private driver all day was free. Tip: we arranged it with Abdul, a super nice guy! (www.abdul-gambia.nl)

reviews.title: Lots of Crocs!
reviews.text: Yes this is good to do if staying in the area, but you will need a taxi to get there. The park itself is off the main highway and at the bottom of a very local impoverished area. Entrance fee is 100 dalasi per adult (guides/drivers free). You don't need a guide for this attraction. There's a very small museum beside the park, a very short walk to the crocodile pool and that's all there is. You can “stroke” the albino crocodile, see others lying around in the sun and there's opportunity to make a donation towards the cost of feeding them. Allow 30-45 mins max for this attraction. Truthfully the poverty on the streets surrounding the park was more of an experience and impacting than seeing the crocodiles but that's the reality of living in The Gambia….for some life is very hard.

reviews.title: A very worthwhile trip.
reviews.text: My wife and I visited the crocodile pool whilst on a recent holiday in Bakau. We hired the services of an excellent local tour guide, Babucarr Fofana. Babu's office is in a street kiosk directly in front of the Ocean Bay Hotel in Bakau. Babu took us on a walk around Bakau to see some sights we were interested in. We went to the National Botanical Gardens, where Babu organized for us to tour the gardens with the Director of the gardens, who explained the plant species we were viewing and the relevance of the plants to the Gambia ecology and economy. Babu then took us to the Bakau Community School and onwards to the Katchikally Crocodile Pool. Babu gave us a guided tour of the museum at the pool and then the pool itself. He is a very knowledgeable guide with excellent English. Babu said we would have the opportunity to stroke the crocodiles, but what he hadn't told us was that they are free to roam the grounds. At first we found this a little alarming, but the pool guide explained that the crocodiles were fed every morning and that they would then not be interested in people unless disturbed. Indeed, all the crocodiles were sunning themselves and quite amenable to being stroked....carefully. The purpose of the pool and the crocodiles was explained to us and its continuing importance in Gambian folklore and society. All in all an excellent and interesting trip.

reviews.title: Want to see crocs? Well, you saw them. That’s it.
reviews.text: Maybe twenty or thirty lame crocs sleeping around or inside the pond. They do not move. You may even touch them. That’s it. You sat half an hour in the taxi to get there.

reviews.title: Small nice park
reviews.text:
A small park but very nice to see. Good price, 100 dalasi for one person. Worth a visit! 
Nice to see the crocodiles. Staff was good on the security.

reviews.title: Nice way to spend a few hours
reviews.text: We hired a taxi from our hotel to take us here nice little place to spend a few hours and you can touch the crocs if you dare, it’s only a couple of quid each to get in and has a little museum which was interesting

reviews.title: Short trip
reviews.text: The park was within walking distance of my guesthouse. The entrance fee was 100 D. After a few meters, you're right next to the crocodiles, which you can touch. Afterward, you walk a short distance, where you're shown crocodile eggs and asked for a donation. Overall, an interesting experience.

reviews.title: Nice experience
reviews.text: A local taxi driver drove us to the place - the museum is very small, but the things on display are quite interesting. The pool itself and the opportunity to touch a crocodile - quite unique. The guys at the pool took good care that everyone had a chance to take a picture with an albino crocodile in a safe and organized manner. In general, a place to visit if you want to look the croc in the face :)

reviews.title: Be aware of pickpocketers
reviews.text: Took a guide from outside hotel. offered great information and we were guided through the museum followed by the elephant tree and the croc pool. While we did not have any issues we heard from other visiter their phones got stolen. Be aware.

reviews.title: Beautiful all round
reviews.text:
We visited the crocodile park with Black and White tours.
First there’s a history museum which was very interesting on the history of The Gambia, then a walk do to the crocodile pool.
Wow what lovely creatures.
With guidance we were able to have photographs with the crocodiles and learn how they live and eat.
Great trip all round

reviews.title: absolutly amazing xxx
reviews.text: my gambian friend took me to bakou with my other friends, I truly would urge anyone to visit and pledge a little donation to the guys whom keep these sacred reptiles from harm please donate if you visit as its an amazing expiriense Karen Soreadbury

reviews.title: Educational visit to a well managed and inexpensive nature site.
reviews.text: After paying 100 dalasi each, we passed the small museum walking along a smooth shaded lane to the pool entrance. Here we were with by the middle aged caretaker who gave us a 15 minute tour that included touching the back of a well fed male albino crocodile who was resting peacefully among 15 more of normal color. He showed a video of their morning feeding, tossing plump fish from a full wheelbarrow as the crocs emerged from the pool in increasing numbers. He then guided us along the pool trail pointing out the unapproachable aggressive females and several semi submerged crocs among the 80 that live around this pool. Further along, we stopped to admire an old Kapok with huge buttress roots when a monkey appeared that was nursing babies. Finally we were shown a rice field(matured at the end of the wet season) soon to be harvested and prepared for planting dry season vegetables. Before departing, we signed a book to make a small contribution to feeding the crocs. Delightful ½ hour visit.

reviews.title: exploitation: entrance fee 16€ in Germany is collected but none of it ends up with the owner of the farm
reviews.text: I'm pretty annoyed that entrance fees are being sold on this website for €16, but the owner of the crocodile farm knows nothing about it. I was there and the entrance fee is €2/100 dalasi. He uses that money to farm everything. Not a single one of the €16 reaches them. I'm wondering what's going on???? By what right do the Germans enrich themselves at the expense of already poor people? Here a loaf of bread costs 10 dalasi/18 cents. €16 converts to 878 dalasi, so someone here would be very rich. The residents here eat rice for lunch, afternoon and evening, usually with sorrel or a fruit sauce. They can't afford milk or any other vegetables/fruit. What do you all say about this? I'm of the opinion that you should only book and pay there, and at €2, donations are very welcome. If you donate the €16 on site, you know that the money actually gets there. No one has to queue here. This also applies to the so-called safari tours, which include this farm. I interviewed the owner, so I know. I wanted to know how much the entrance fee was and whether I needed to change money. I was and still am deeply shocked by this result. You wouldn't dare do that in Germany, as you can sue for damages. But I think it's the most audacious thing to line your pockets at the expense of such poor people.

reviews.title: More interesting than expected
reviews.text: Most tourists come here to pet a crocodile – a special experience in itself, given the animals' typically aggressive and reactive nature. However, the complex has also been a pilgrimage site to a (still existing) healing spring for centuries. The history and legend are definitely worth taking in, and perhaps you'll change your perspective... The small museum directly after the entrance provides interesting details about the traditions of Gambia's various tribes. Furthermore, if you keep your eyes open, you might spot a variety of birds and, with luck, other animals as well.

reviews.title: Highlight of our trip.
reviews.text: Loved it here. Great experience and the staff were brilliant. Highlight of our trip. Lovely museum with some interesting history.

reviews.title: Good for quick stop
reviews.text:
The entrance is just 100 dalasis to the museum which will tell you quite a lot about history of Gambia. There is also pretty good toilet. The “pool” is just a few seconds walk from the museum and it is “free” as it is included in museum fee. I am seriously against to touching while animals and make me sad that so many people taking “cool” photos while “sitting” on crocodiles. 
There are 3 parts … one where you can go to crocodiles very close and touch them. Pool where you can’t go close to them as they are aggressive (well that’s their nature right?) and then where you can see babies.  I have had great guy to talk to and we were joking and talking not just about crocodiles but life generally. You can contribute some money if you wish to keep this place running and I think it’s worth it

reviews.title: Don't Expect Much
reviews.text:
After visiting the Crocodile Pool. 

The Museum is small but very informative/interesting history of the Gambia. You will learn about the ancestral rituals, music, history of the British colonisation until recent days...By itself this was a good highlight for me.

The Crocodile Pool itself, is a rather muddy pool surrounded by trees and occupied by an assortment of tame crocodiles that do very little. Didnt take any photos with the crocodiles, because it didnt felt right for me.

It is an Okay way to spend an hour or two. Just don't expect a major tourist attraction

reviews.title: Enjoyed The Guided Tour
reviews.text: Take some fish with you and watch them been fed your offering, great guided tour and entertaining comments

reviews.title: We stroked a crocodile
reviews.text:
First there is some interesting museum
pieces about the tribes etc. Then you go to the pool. The guy who looks after the crocs really knows them well and you can tell he cares for them. You can stroke the crocodile under the supervision of their keeper. 
Plenty of opportunity to donate to the upkeep of the crocs. Don’t buy the exercise books on offer at the price they ask for, so much cheaper in the shops!

reviews.title: Interesting excursion
reviews.text: The site actually starts with a small museum with different rooms on Gambian culture - traditions, music, war etc. Then you go to see the crocodiles where the knowledgable keeper will tell you all about them and you can take photos. I think entry is 100D and then you can make a donation to the care of the crocodiles too. Good place to combine with other places to visit - we then went to Serekunda Market.

reviews.title: Touching crocodiles
reviews.text: It's a must-see if you come to Gambia. Even better if you have children. The visit begins with a small museum dedicated to the history of Bakau, where you can see historical photographs and traditional artifacts (costumes, drums, juju, etc.). The elephant's foot tree before reaching the crocodile enclosure is very spectacular. Although the crocodile pool isn't spectacularly large, it makes up for it with the opportunity to take photos touching the crocodiles.

reviews.title: Close up experience
reviews.text: If you have never been close to animals like these before it's probably a life times experience for you, although they are so well fed they are not very active but it is possible to touch them which gives most people a thrill. Should visit this place if just for the historic connection of Katchikally.

reviews.title: Lots and lots of crocodiles including the elusive albino Charlie
reviews.text: This was a really bizarre experience. The guide was telling us that it was perfectly safe to stroke the crocodiles and have photos taken with them. The reptiles were practically comatose, now bearing in mind that they are cold blooded creatures, they should have been very lively indeed in a temperature of 34-36 degrees. When asked about the state of their inertia we were told that they have been trained to only perceive fish as food, which l am sorry to say was a complete and utter load of Croc! They were undoubtedly sedated which was very sad to see and l and 1 other in our group refused to participate in such a farce.

reviews.title: Interesting museum and crocodile pool
reviews.text: Place was easy to locate - look out for the colorful wall It cost $100 to visit the museum and pool Although museum was small it had a lot of info about the music, culture, women, history and nature of Gambia Thé croc pool was small but interesting as gâtés were left open You are encouraged to wander inside, with guide to bring you close to them which we declined We prefer to let sleeping crocodiles alone The kids were more aggressive though - with endless demands for soccer balls, physical items, money and all things under the sum. Watch out for them instead.

reviews.title: ... quite short but unique pleasure
reviews.text: Surprisingly, it was actually a rather short experience. The advertised crocodile pool turned out to be a rather small pond with many crocodiles. Thankfully, they were all well-fed, practically full, so we were able to pet and touch the crocodiles lying around outside without fear. There's also a small museum about the history of Gambia nearby. All in all, it was a pretty decent trip, especially since on the way there and back, through the nearby villages, you can also gain insight into the way of life of the Gambians. We paid the equivalent of €60 for this.

reviews.title: Great experience
reviews.text: A must-do for a visit to Banjul because it's an incredible experience. You risk absolutely nothing, and yet I wasn't convinced. The guides are very friendly and will reassure you if you still have reservations. A must-do. 100D, it's cheap, so a small donation is required :)

reviews.title: Fun!
reviews.text: A piccolo museo, a tour in the forest and this pool in which live coccodrilli that if you can touch. In fact, we are outside, but we are all here 🤷🏼‍♀️. The legend says che chi si bagna nelle sue acque riceve figli o fortune, a seconda di ciò che desidera. Of course, if you don't get inside, an addetto recovers a cold water seal. I enjoyed cooking a little with this tourist area. Discarica to open sky, fire to open sky, so much povertà.. mio marito, gambiano lui stesso, c'è rimasto male.

reviews.title: Filthy pool, to many crocs in a to small environment
reviews.text: The reason we went there is the small museum. There you can learn about the culture, especially Mandinka, but also about history. We loved it

reviews.title: Strange, different but wonderful!!
reviews.text:
What a great place! This is not a zoo, this is where the crocodiles choose to stay and live, they are free to leave if they want, we loved to see this natural place and pool and the crocodiles are very calm, looks peaceful!
Ask your guide and they will help you! Count on about 2 hours to walk around! Bring some cash and give about 5-10€ in tip inside to the crocodile manager, the money is for fish to feed the crocodiles in the mornings!
Well worth the time and that small amount of money!

reviews.title: Śpiące krokodyle
reviews.text:
W porze suchej dla krokodyli jest za gorąco. Śpią w cieniu. Można je spokojnie dotknąć (pod nadzorem).
Dziwne uczucie. Na żart mojej żony "że chyba są z plastkiku"-pan sie zdenerwował i złapał gada za ogon i zaczął ciągną. Ten sie obudził , wyrwał i uciekł do wody.

reviews.title: Nærkontakt med krokodiller
reviews.text: Her kan du gå rundt et lite tjern der det er fullt av krokodiller 2-3 meter lange. Man må gå me en guide som kjenner krokodillene og vet hvilke som er aggressive and hvilke som er rolige. Man har også muligheten til å klappe en stor krokodille. Det er altså ingen gjerder eller stengsler mellom besøkende og krokodillene. Then you can see what you're looking for, but you don't have to worry about it. Er det virkelig trygt? Og har de gjort noe med krokodillene for at de skal holde seg rolige? Ikke vet jeg, men jeg skal ihvertfall ikke tilbake hit.

reviews.title: Crocodile Park
reviews.text: I visited the crocodile park. I found the Museum small but very informative with a lot of history. I was shocked to see a crocodile just lay in the park, unmoving with its mouth wide open, the only thing that moved was its eyes, it must surly be drugged to stay like this. I did have a photo taken with it, like every one else but I now wish I hadn't

reviews.title: Petting a crocodile for 100 dalasi... well
reviews.text: Entrance fee: 100 dalasi. Petting a crocodile (queue, very commercial) another 100 dalasi. From the entrance, there's a pretty good museum you can walk through about the history of Gambia. If you bring your own taxi driver (he gets in free), he can explain more. Then you enter a kind of small park with a lake where some crocodiles lie in or near it. If you want to pet one (which doesn't eat meat, but fish), you have to wait in line for your turn. After petting, you have to sign your name in a book and pay. You'll be back outside in half an hour. The "pool" is in a poor neighborhood; children will rush at you the moment you get out of the taxi. Bring some wrapped cookies, candy, or lollipops—they'll be very happy.

reviews.title: Z gadami
reviews.text: Bardzo ciekawe miejsce, krokodyle swobodnie bez klatek wylegują się na polanie aTy możesz go dotknąć byle nie w głowę. Polecam

reviews.title: Crocs up close
reviews.text: Great to be able to touch these terrifying animals. Amazing to see up close. and in a natural environment.

reviews.title: Crocodiles
reviews.text: He gave us a tour with our private guide. First, a bit of Gambian history. Very interesting, and I noticed the guide's emotion. Then we went to the crocodiles. They're fed fish instead of meat, which calms them down and makes them less aggressive. Yes, this allows you to touch them. I was a bit nervous, but I'm glad I did. We did this together with the man who works there, who also tells interesting stories and has a good sense of humor.

reviews.title: Inget att besöka
reviews.text: Inte värt ett besök, var krokodilerna drogade?? De mest intressanta var att vi gick hem efter besöket hos crocsen, rekommenderas att gå genom området för att få träffa lokal befolkningen. Det är fritt att gå i parken, man måste inte anlita en guide, vilket dom gärna vill att man gör.

reviews.title: Great place
reviews.text:
Well there can’t be many places in the world where you can have your photo taken stroking a crocodile.
The history of this sacred pool is very interesting and being so close to the crocodiles is an amazing experience.

reviews.title: Crocodiles are really cute creatures!
reviews.text: Visit with a local guide. First, the museum with some history, voodoo rituals, and local musical instruments. Then a walk through some forest, and suddenly you're standing among a herd of crocodiles enjoying being petted and massaged. A lovely experience.

reviews.title: If you have never seen a croc....
reviews.text:
If you have seen crocs before: Don't go!
If you have not and are with children: You might consider!
If you go alone: Take a taxi! The streets to the Pool are narrow, dirty and VERY lokal.

reviews.title: Spotkanie z krokodylem
reviews.text:
Zobaczysz oraz dotkniesz krokodyla w tym parku. Krokodyle chodzą swobodnie po obiekcie bez klatek oraz bez terrariów. Gady karmione są rybami przez obsługę. W porze suchej krokodyle nie wykazuj dużej aktywności, w przeciwieństwie do pory deszczowej gdzie ich aktywność znacznie wzrasta.
Polecam wycieczkę z lokalnym przewodnikiem:
Travor J,  WhatsApp number +2203113578
https://pl.tripadvisor.com/Profile/alasanaj2020?fid=04065aa2-e2d1-4f07-b51d-c20a68cfbf31

You will see and touch a crocodile in this park. Crocodiles walk freely around the object without cages and without terrariums. The reptiles are fed by fish by service. In the dry season, crocodiles do not show much activity, unlike the rainy season, where their activity increases significantly.
I recommend a trip with a local guide:
Travor J,  WhatsApp number +2203113578
https://pl.tripadvisor.com/Profile/alasanaj2020?fid=04065aa2-e2d1-4f07-b51d-c20a68cfbf31

reviews.title: Close to the crocodiles
reviews.text: A small museum about Gambian voodoo and musical instruments, and a pool full of crocodiles. Interesting to see.

reviews.title: petting crocodiles
reviews.text: Nice excursion in Gambia with crocodile petting as a highlight, also a nice little museum on the site

reviews.title: 6 in 1 Trip
reviews.text: One of our excursions, and part of the 6 in 1. Very good especially stroking the crocodiles with a walk around the park.

reviews.title: Crocodile pool
reviews.text: We visited it with a local guide. It was special to walk among the crocodiles. The walk there made a big impression on me. You see a bit of real Gambian life. We walked back through the local market. Bizarre.

reviews.title: Not big but nice!
reviews.text: We went there and it was just a short trip from sun beach hotel just 20 min. walk through bakau. They have an albino crocodile there Charlie which is portriad in the watermark on the money. If you're lucky you can see him but he's in the water a lot

reviews.title: Krokotiili lammikko
reviews.text: Pääsi taputtelemaan krokotiileja jotka jäähdyttelivät varjossa tai auringossa kidat auki. Vaikka vaikuttavia petoja tuntui kuin ne olisi huumattu, mutta hoitajien mukaan ei. Vaikea löytää ilman paikallista taksia

reviews.title: Crocodile excursion
reviews.text: It's wonderful to see how these animals are protected in a peaceful environment and well cared for!

reviews.title: Cute little place
reviews.text: Little museum on the way in then time to get close to the crocs, a guide will talk you through the history and take pics for you, try to take pens, books etc for the local kids as they are all there when you come out (there's a little shop if you aren't prepared)

reviews.title: Nice to go there
reviews.text: Nice to look at, but it is not that big, you walk one lap and then you are out again, but there is a lot of information at the beginning about the country

reviews.title: Nice to experience
reviews.text: It was fun to experience walking among the crocodiles. You could touch one of the crocodiles. The guide was friendly and explained everything well.

reviews.title: Petting crocodiles
reviews.text: The crocodile pool is fun to visit, though small, but enjoyable. The museum explains the land itself, making it interesting. Then it's a short walk to the crocodiles, where you can touch some of them.

reviews.title: Quite different!
reviews.text: A good local trip and interesting museum that explains a great deal of the Gambian History. The crocs were very "crocy"

reviews.title: Nice to visit
reviews.text: If you visit the crocodile pool, you can also visit the Bakau Museum. It's not large, but it's definitely worth a visit. We went with a guide who told us a lot about the history. The crocodile pool is a fun place to visit. It's a large pond with 100 crocodiles, some of which you can touch. The holy water brings prosperity and fertility to couples who are involuntarily childless (or so the story goes). It's simply a fun outing. The entrance fee is 100 Dalasi, so that's definitely worth it.

reviews.title: Lite obehagligt
reviews.text: Först ett museum med bl a traditionella dräkter som används vid festen i samband med den kvinnliga omskärelsen. Sedan ett gäng stora lösa krokodiler som de ville att vi skulle klappa och köpa mat till. Jag är mest glad att vi inte blev uppätna själva!

reviews.title: Lagom läskigt
reviews.text:
Trevlig liten oas med lagom spänningsfaktor. Vi hade egen guide med oss, men parkens egna var också väldigt trevlig.
Litet museum i anslutning till entrén om Gambias olika stammar. Förvånansvärt fräscha toaletter.

reviews.title: Värt ett besök
reviews.text: It is located in the Gambias history. Vi var där med en local kille “guide”, vilket är det bästa attt göra tycker vi. Sedan klapde “gubben” på en av krokodilerna. Det var en ”krokodilguide” på dishes, så det var inte så attt man kunde springa runt och klappa hur som helst. Själv höll jag mig lite på avstånd. Respect! Krokodilerna matas varje dag och det går åt 250 kg fisk dagligen. De matas interme med kött. Detta skall göra krokodilerna mätta och det är därför de är dåsiga och inte attackerar folk. Dock såg vi en som verkade aggressiv, men den gillade inte attt bli störd. Området är inte stort, men det ska finnas ca 80 stycken där.

reviews.title: You get really close to crocodiles
reviews.text: This place is great!  You can actulally pet one of the crocodiles.  The history of how the pool was established was interesting.  Worth a visit!

reviews.title: A place to get close to crocodiles
reviews.text: Quite an experience!  Not for those scared of crocodiles.  The pool is full and you can watch them moving about and climbing out of the water and walking near you.  The staff are friendly and give advice on how to approach the crocodiles and touch them.  Have been several times and the place always fascinates.  The museum is interesting but tired.

reviews.title: Hidden in the village - OK for a 15-minute visit
reviews.text: The park is essentially a pond with crocodiles, which, because they're heavily fed, basically just lie around. The highlight is petting the crocodiles, but it's not particularly exciting. You can do it to tick off the box.

reviews.title: Super miejsce
reviews.text:
Polecam zdecydowanie, cena to 100 dalasi. 
Można dotknąć krokodyle. I zobaczyc nie wielkie muzeum. 
Fajna sprawa !

reviews.title: Halvtama krokodiler.
reviews.text: Efter man betalat inträdet tar guiden med besökaren till museet till höger innanför ingången. Det finns en stig som leder runt inom området och där får man känslan att man befinner sig i en djungel ! Bra guider !

reviews.title: Very touristy.
reviews.text: Exciting to get up close to the crocodiles. Cheap trip. The pond isn't clean and there are too many crocodiles in it. Very touristy.

reviews.title: Less than expected
reviews.text: The Crocodile Pool is advertised as a large pool. It's actually just one pool, and can be done in 10 minutes. However, there are plenty of crocodiles. A tip is expected in addition to the entrance fee.

reviews.title: Petting crocodiles
reviews.text: The entrance fee is 100 Gambian guineas. The museum of Gambian history is modern and rivals the National Museum (though that's not so difficult). The crocodiles, numbering around 70, have lived around this lake for a very long time. The population maintains itself by not growing very large and by using methods of birth control. People should do this too. Touching the crocodiles is allowed. Every now and then one will snap at you in irritation, but most crocodiles are mainly refueling.

reviews.title: Dirty water and small
reviews.text: We were a bit hesitant about going there beforehand, but we finally went ahead with it. It's accessible and inexpensive, but it's just a dirty little lake with far too many crocodiles. That can't be good. Not a must-see.

reviews.title: Surprise loose crocodiles, there is a museum with explanations of traditions
reviews.text: They say they don't attack because they only eat fish. My theory is that they don't attack because they're fed every day. I gave a tip so they'd buy food.

reviews.title: As is so often the case, the journey is the destination.
reviews.text: If you do the tour yourself, get an SUV. The roads are otherwise barely passable. But along the way, you get a glimpse into how the people here live and how poor the country is. The park itself? Well, okay. With a guide who shows you the museum, you get a brief insight into the history of Gambia, and if you like, you can pet crocodiles. It takes 30 minutes. It costs 1-2 euros.

reviews.title: many crocodiles
reviews.text: When we were in Gambia, our guide took us to the crocodile pool, among other things. It was actually quite scary, but you can pet them. Very strange, too, but it was fun to experience it once.

reviews.title: Not great
reviews.text: There is a small museum at the entrance, very small park, we came out disappointed... We thought we would see about ten, or even maybe dozens of crocodiles but in the end we saw 3... Maybe we were unlucky but we didn't see the point of going there... We pay the entrance fee, we see 3 crocodiles then they ask us for money so they can buy food for the crocodiles... I don't recommend it

reviews.title: Great Expierience
reviews.text:
Me and my girlfriend went it was an amazing experience 
You get very close to the crocodiles and can even touch them 
Definitely a must when in Gambia

reviews.title: Quite nice and worthwhile
reviews.text: The complex houses a small museum where several masks are on display and the history of Gambia is briefly discussed. It was quite nice to see the reptiles up close and pet them. Be sure to bring mosquito repellent on this excursion. It costs about €2 for 100 dalasi, and it's absolutely worth it.

reviews.title: Esperienza piacevole.
reviews.text: Certo, passeggiare tra i coccodrilli non è una cosa molto comune però è stato bello vedere questi animali da vicino. Il parco è un po' troppo piccoli per ospitare tutti quegli animali, alcuni dei quali sono davvero grandi!

reviews.title: Educational and fun
reviews.text: When you enter, you pay and can go into the museum. There you'll find a lot about Gambian culture: lifestyle, witchcraft, music, presidents, etc. Very educational indeed. As soon as you step outside, you'll immediately see crocodiles roaming freely and lying around. For a few euros, you can have a personal guide who can tell you all about the place, including the white crocodile and infertile women. At the end of the tour, you can make a donation. This money is used to feed the crocodiles. If you really want to make a difference, buy some fish at the market first and take it home with you.

reviews.title: Crocodile is captive, yet you feel free!
reviews.text: Crocodile pool, nothing special, but fun to check out! Even the ride there is an experience :)

reviews.title: Family vacation
reviews.text: This time, it's just my wife and I. Our fears would probably be put to rest, but the animals are surely very well fed.

reviews.title: Annorlunda upplevelse
reviews.text: Vägen till parken är i sig en upplevelse. In äkta gambiansk by me vattenbrunn på torget, korrigerade plåtskjul och oblyga barn som vill hålla handen. I parked in the dark so that it could be stored. De är helt fria inne i parken och du får anpassa dig efter var de är. Vi fick veta att de blir matade varje morgon så att de inte är hungriga när turisterna kommer... så därför är de helt ofarliga.... ;-) Parken är rätt liten men ändå väl värd ett besök.

reviews.title: Extraordinary experience
reviews.text: After more than 20 years, I returned here, and it was another fantastic experience. Besides the crocodiles, which you can actually touch, there's also a small museum at the entrance that briefly covers the history and culture of Gambia. You should get a green taxi to visit the place relatively undisturbed, and perhaps also take a trip to the Bakau fish market from there.

reviews.title: Crocodile park
reviews.text: This place you have to visit, if you go to Gambia. Crocodiles are free inside this park and you go there to they area. You can touch one of the crocodile, call Charlie and that was quite schary, but it was safety. There is "nanny"  with you and they told, that they give 250 kg fish every day to crocodiles, so they are calm. Must visit place.

reviews.title: Special..................
reviews.text: A unique encounter with these reptiles without any protection... No fences, walls, or anything, and then you're even allowed to "pet" these reptiles... Well, you have to like them!

reviews.title: Very impressive
reviews.text: We were in the park with a large group. Petting the crocodiles was a wonderful experience. As already mentioned, the crocodiles are fed fish.

reviews.title: Sure, why not. Pet a croc.
reviews.text: It is an interesting place,no doubt. I ve seen and held crocodiles before so maybe I was bit more immune to the excitement other people experienced. Still, it was a good way to spend some time and the opportunity to touch them and pet them is great. You can get some nice pics. I still keep wondering why were they so lazy, even to eat a fish, barely moving,almost all of them. I ve been assured they are not sedated, just overfed... .

reviews.title: Impressive with oppressive feeling
reviews.text: It's quite brave to stand among several crocodiles over 2 meters long. Touching them (if you dare) is a unique experience. A small donation is welcome. The guide explains everything and leads us through the complex. We appreciated the authenticity and the fact that commercialism hasn't yet taken hold. We took a taxi there on our own, and the four of us were the only visitors that afternoon.

reviews.title: Fantastic!
reviews.text: What a great place! Really enjoyed going around the museums, very interesting, but absolutely loved seeing the crocodiles, I got to stroke one, which is a first for me. Wonderful experience!

reviews.title: Very beautiful small park
reviews.text: Very nice experience, you can touch the crocodiles, they are not drugged, some move slowly and when the guard gives an order, they lie down. Entrance 100 dalasis (museum and crocodiles)

reviews.title: Lamgil trips
reviews.text:
Another leg  of our excellent trip with lamin (lamgil trips and excursions).

The guy who talks with s brilliant English accent talks with passion how he looks after the crocodiles.

A brilliant experience and please leave a tip as this is how he feeds the crocodiles.

Brilliant

reviews.title: It's fun to pet a crocodile
reviews.text: It's not much to look at in itself, but if you're in the area, you might as well take the opportunity to pet a crocodile. It's not expensive to get in. You'll see a small museum, and afterward, you can pet a crocodile, and you'll receive some explanation.

reviews.title: Crocodiles
reviews.text: The crocodiles can be petted, as they are fed only fish from birth. The park is nicely laid out, and the guides are friendly and explain everything well. However, you have to be aware that the pool is located in one of the poorest neighborhoods in the city. It's hard to imagine how people live there. We walked there and met friendly and helpful people everywhere.

reviews.title: Excellent
reviews.text:
Until now the closest I had ever come to seeing the crocodile was through the television
I know you can see them in a zoo but it’s not the Same as seeing them for real this beats the Zoo experience

reviews.title: Spännande upplevelse
reviews.text: Med ett visst mått av skräckblandad förtjusning besökte vi stället. Vi tog mod till oss och klappade ett par av krokodilerna utan att bli av med en enda kroppsdel 😊

reviews.title: Old Crocs
reviews.text: Worth a visit but nothing to write home about, the small museum before you go in is very interesting and tells how life was in the earlier days.

reviews.title: Petting crocodiles
reviews.text: The 'Katchikally Sacred Crocodile Pond' may not be the most spectacular activity in Bakau, but it is certainly special to walk among six crocodiles and rub or pet one or more (on their backs). Where else can you do this? We visited Katchikally as part of the half-day Orientation Tour organized by African Adventure Travel & Tours. We booked the tour through the Corendon tour guide; price: €30 per person. This visit is part of the local color of the coastal town of Bakau and is therefore highly recommended. You can also do this on your own; it's a 20-minute walk from the Sun Beach hotel (Kofi Annan Street) to the pool. It might be advisable to have a local guide (you can find them everywhere near the hotels), as the last 500 meters lead through some alleys and alleys – at least by our standards – where you might not feel completely at ease. The pond isn't particularly large; you can walk all the way around it in less than 10 minutes. A guide will explain its history and the water's supposed fertility-promoting properties. So, anyone who wants to shower with this water is welcome to do so. A small museum has been set up at the entrance. Unfortunately, due to the limited English spoken during the tour, some of the information is overlooked. But having a photo taken with a crocodile is always a souvenir...

reviews.title: Interesting and accessible
reviews.text: If you're spending your holiday on the west coast, this is a great attraction if you have an hour to spare. We were there with our guide, Buba, and he knows a lot about the crocodiles, but also about their natural predators! It's not very big; there's a small museum and a beautiful tree. An hour is plenty. Interesting to visit and inexpensive.

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text:
What an amazing experience from when you arrive to see the interesting museum with local instruments and the history of The Gambia, then on to the crocodile pool. not quite knowing what to expect its surreal to see the crocodile roaming free and to be able to touch them. All this for 100 GD.
 bargain.

reviews.title: Spännande
reviews.text: Vi var där för fem år sedan förra gången. Nu återvände vi med ett barnbarn på 4,5 år. Väldigt annorlunda att upptäcka allt på nytt med ett barn. Absolut ska man dit och klappa krokodiler. Skillnaden denna gång var att det ”tiggdes” pengar till krokodilmat. Vår lokalguide avrådde oss.

reviews.title: Crocodiles you can touch
reviews.text: We cycled there as a group from the BB Hotel, past embassies and residences, and also along the sandy paths of the town. The contrasts are stark. But even the poor population is very, very friendly. At the entrance to the park, you first visit the museum about the country's history, then the path through the park, past the giant silk tree, to the crocodile pond. Guides provide in-depth explanations, and then—if you're so inclined—you can pet free-roaming crocodiles with a view. A worthwhile visit, highly recommended.

reviews.title: Crocodile pool
reviews.text: The guide knows all the crocodiles and will tell you all the ins and outs! It's special to be able to see and touch crocodiles up close! The small museum is also worth a visit.

reviews.title: Crocodiles + museum = experience!
reviews.text:
Read somewhere that people had written that the museum on site wasnt according to the ”standard” they were used to. I think these people have the wrong expectations.

The museum and the park itself is small but it tells you a lots of stories about The Gambia; history, politics, people, the different tribes and their customs (clothes, instruments). I got a lot of insights during this visit, and I am thrilled to understand some of the differences and similarities between the different tribes.

Walking towards the crocodile pool we passed a -huge- tree with a hollow body that could encircle ten of us (photo session time), a lots of other trees and lianes (shadow!), and fields were the women work with the family crops (photo session time).

The crocodile pool was at first glance not that much to talk about, but suddenly they were crawling up to meet us and there were crocodiles everywhere. Cool and a bit scary :)

If you want to be close to a crocodile, go here. If you dont, stay home.
And, dont be stupid, they are still crocodiles even when they are recently fed ;)

reviews.title: Visited Crocodile Charlie and petted a Crocodile.
reviews.text: Great crocodile pool. Friendly staff. It's nice to see one up close and be able to touch it without any danger.

reviews.title: Tama Krokodiler....
reviews.text:
Ja det låter märkligt men det är verkligen tama dessa …. gjorde inte mig mindre rädd men man kan klappa den =) 
det är en liten pool... naturpool man kan gå runt med ca 200 krokodiler…. ligger i Bakau så det är ingen lång utflykt men kanske 1-2 timmar

reviews.title: Dont expect to much
reviews.text: We took a taxi from the hotel, about £3, and he waited for us.  At the end of a narrow track is the crocodile pool, a small fee of about £1 to enter.  There is a small museum which is interesting and crocodiles lying around a pool.  They are wandering around freely so dont stand too close.  There is a stall and a lady making tea.  A nice afternoon visit.

reviews.title: Pieni pettymys
reviews.text: Koko paikka oli pettymys. Pääsi kyllä koskettelemaan krokodiilin mutta. Paikka oli yksi pieni kuoppa missä eleli kuulemma monta sataa krokotiiliä, rahaa halusivat sisäänpääsyn lisäksi vielä sisällä krokotiilien ylläpitämiseen.

reviews.title: Nature at its finest
reviews.text: With a historical museum to walk through, educating us of Gambian soldiers who fought in the world war and local traditional practices, and much more was a nice informative way to start of a great trip. To see crocodiles up close in the flesh, at such peace is a true experience. Been twice now once with and once without children. Both very enjoyable experiences.

reviews.title: Overcall
reviews.text: A visit lasts a maximum of 10 minutes, during which you can touch one crocodile, and then you walk around a pool of about 100 other crocodiles. It certainly doesn't seem a bit sad, but it's certainly not well-maintained.

reviews.title: Okay
reviews.text: There was nothing worth writing home about. Just a bunch of zonked crocodiles which wasn’t really my idea of interesting but was recommended by one of the locals. A bit overpriced but thankfully negotiable. It’s better suited for families, I’m sure children would enjoy the experience more.

reviews.title: An experience
reviews.text: We did not realise when we booked this trip that the crocs are roaming free. We enjoyed the experience of being up close, touching and sitting on one of them. It was a very small place and a quick trip.

reviews.title: Give it a miss
reviews.text:
Highly overrated and a real tourist con as has been the case for a long time 
The crocodile that you are able to feel is heavily drugged.
A total waste of time.

reviews.title: nice place to visit
reviews.text: the beach around this restaurant is great, very quiet and beautiful. We only had drinks here but we enjoyed the quiet and lack of people who want to sell you little knickknacks. the crocodiles were sleeping, we sadly missed the feeding. It would be nice if they had a note somewhere when they will feed the crocodiles, otherwise a nice place to be

reviews.title: Stroke a crocodile!
reviews.text:
Sacred and historic crocodile pool stocked with West African crocodiles. Crocodiles are well fed and used to being approached by humans. Informative museum.
Need a guide to find as not signposted from the road.

reviews.title: Intressant möte
reviews.text: Utan att ha bokat något så tog vi en taxi till denna krokodilpark. Vi gick runt i deras museum som kanske inte höll den standard som viär vana vid på ett museum men en hel del intressant information fans där. Väl framme vid krokodilerna så fick vi en man som följde med oss och informarade glatt om alla krokodiler. Ju mer vi frågade de este gladare blev han och berättade gärna allt han viste. Spännande att luta sig halvvägs in i en krokodils gap när den låg och solade sig samt att få klappa dem lite i deras vila. Väl värt ett besök. Admission costs 100 dalasi per person.

reviews.title: Lots of crocs!!!
reviews.text:
Loads of crocs & can get really close to some. Difficult to find but just ask a local.
Small museum on local culture.

reviews.title: Wonderful
reviews.text: Excellent food, great staff and a beautiful location.  The seafood is wonderful, home grown herbs and salads, good wine and garlic bread to die for!  Live music by two talented guys made the evenings special.

reviews.title: Few Crocodiles
reviews.text: Overhyped- has to travel a long way to see a few lazy crodiles. Everywhere busters inside and out hassling you to touch the crocodile etc for money. Never leaves you alone

reviews.title: Was determined not to go
reviews.text: Before leaving the UK this was one place I had made up my mind I definitely wasn't going. However, we booked a last minute day trip - and this was included so I decided to brave it. I wasn't aware of the museum at the start so that was nice and very interesting addition. Particularly enjoyed the instruments which our guide said I was allowed to have a go on. On the walk from the museum to the crocodile pond there's a very interesting tree trunk formation which you can walk inside. Don't miss it. I was so busy walking and talking to the guide I didn't realize til I was right upon the crocodiles! I thought my heart would stop. They were laying across the couch, motionless with their mouths wide opened (this is how they cool off). There were some others with their mouth closed and the pool guide invited us to come stroke them. It took me over 15 minutes of coercion to gently touch one with my finger. The guides are really good, patient and knowledgeable. There's a little gift shop there. I found it impossible to relax at all whilst there as I was so scared but once I'd left a sense of adrenaline overcame me and I couldn't believe I had braved it. Guide took a great photo of the inside of one of the opened mouths. Good, clean toilet.

reviews.title: Too commercial.
reviews.text: Your visit lasts 5 minutes. A pit with many crocodiles and one you can touch. For someone who's never seen a crocodile at our zoo, that's fine.

reviews.title: Tourist trap
reviews.text: It's nice if you have kids but it's a bit of a tourist trap.  It looks like the crocodiles are drugged.

reviews.title: Crocodile Dundee
reviews.text: Okay, touching a crocodile is a truly amazing experience, to be honest, but personally, I wasn't particularly impressed with the crocodile pool. Perhaps the surroundings were a bit too small for me. At the entrance, you first encounter a museum, then you see some truly enormous trees, and then you arrive directly at a small pond with a dozen crocodiles basking in the sun. It all felt a bit unnatural, even though it's naturally occurring. It's probably also due to the fence you walk past to reach the crocodiles... Incidentally, it's a sacred place for the Gambians, and they're positively focused on finding the right partners and having healthy children! That mindset is certainly beautiful!😊

reviews.title: Small and uncomfortable
reviews.text: The crocodiles were small and just everywhere. Some you could pet/touch and some you shouldn’t go near. It was really small there and not big at all. Wouldn’t have visited it if it wasn’t on the tour we went on.

reviews.title: Don't miss this
reviews.text: What an experience! Very cheap to get in, lovely little museum at the start, the crocodiles roam around, I touched one!!! Our guide was brilliant telling us all about the crocs and it was really interesting, I'm so glad we visited, highly recommended

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: The park was within walking distance of our hotel however we incorporated this into a tour day with Abilie Jobe( his stand is opposite Ocean Bay Hotel he is a great guide excellent English speaker very knowledgable and much cheaper than the tour operators price) I got to stroke a crocodile. The museum at the park is very interesting 100 Dalasi just over a £1.

reviews.title: visit
reviews.text: Walked on the beach to see the pool. Crocodiles were too sleepy to take any notice. We're not hungry.

reviews.title: NOT for faint hearted!
reviews.text:
An amazing experience that i do not think you can do anywhere else on earth and 100% NOT in Europe!!!

Get upclose and personal with one of the most deadliest animals on earth.

You literally ENTER the home of these crocs that walk around freely, just one rule DO NOT touch them by the head area if you want to come out in one piece! 

I cannot recommend this place highly enough! Also there is a museum that is really educational.

reviews.title: Fascinating Place to Visit
reviews.text:
We were brought here by our guide for the day. A fascinating place to visit where the sleepy crocs come out of the water to relax in the sun. They look very relaxed and seem used to visitors touching them.
There's a small museum to visit on the site and some unusual birds to observe within the grounds of the pond.
We could also see the local ladies working on the adjoining allotments where they draw water from a well and then use a bucket with holes in the bottom to water their crops - slow hard work!

reviews.title: A must.
reviews.text: Had an amazing time visiting this centre, our guide was most informative. Paid 100 Dallas I on entry, but tipped our guide for his work.

reviews.title: Lovely
reviews.text:
A really enjoyable visit to the crocodile pool, thanks to my local guide from Gambia friendly tours..
I will definately come back next time i visit.

reviews.title: Интересно.
reviews.text: Посетили ферму во время обзорной экскурсии. Представляет собой небольшой заиленный пруд, где живут крокодилы и небольшой парк из диковинных для нас растений( огромные баобабы, хлопковое дерево и т.д.). Когда мы пришли, крокодильчики ждали на берегу, и каждый из нас мог контактировать с этими  "милыми существами” на сколько хватит фантазии и смелости. Я тихонечко подержалась за хвост и впечатлений мне хватило.

reviews.title: Amazing to stroke them
reviews.text: Went along to the pool and quite a few crocodiles. Texture of them is very strange but well done to the staff and guide. An experience well worth it

reviews.title: Great hidden gem
reviews.text:
Great place to visit, has a small museum with aincent masks and musical instruments together with the history of The Gambia.
A short walk and your at the pool, surprisingly small but has lots of crocodiles. You actually get the chance to touch and feel a real crocodile 
This is a charity so all donations are welcome, a few locals selling their souvenirs but no hard sell
or hassle 
Well worth a visit

reviews.title: Average
reviews.text: lots of crocodiles but not a lot of movement. Asked for extra money to support the crocodiles. Take hand wash with yu as you are asked to touch the crocodiles.

reviews.title: everything OK
reviews.text: The trip there was African style, how can I explain it? It's worth seeing around Banjul. The tour was good. The number of crocodile teeth they sell there can't have come from these enclosures.

reviews.title: Interesting visit
reviews.text:
Good way to pass a couple of hours strolling tgrough tge museum and getting to know a bit about the history of Gambia. The crocodiles are fed twice a day and happy to be stroked and photographed following the guides instructions. 
There are around 100 crocodiles that roam free in and around the pool area, so watch where you walk. There are also lizards roaming around and a fascinating Elephant tree. Well worth a visit.

reviews.title: The trip was as good as the crocs
reviews.text: We met a lovely person on the beach named JoJo that took us on the trip. It started with a walk (15 minutes) through "the real africa" where the Gambian people lived their day to day lives. This walk was a big "eye-opener" and gave me and my girlfriend a lot of emotions, to see how they REALLY live. You can't experience that at the hotels. Then we arrived at a small museum where we learned about The Gambia. And after that we meet the reptiles. It's crazy how close you can get to these beasts. But it's very safe and the owners are there to comfort you, haha. I can really recommend this trip. And I want to give a big shoutout to our new friend JoJo. He made our Gambian vacation a lot better. If you want to experience The Gambia I really recommend you guys to contact JoJo.

reviews.title: It's not worth it
reviews.text: The only interesting thing about the site is a beautiful 300-year-old tree. The crocodiles are crammed into a small natural pool. There was one outside that they let you touch; it looked drugged. It was pitiful to see the animals...

reviews.title: Crocs....
reviews.text: We came here as part of our 6 in 1 day tour. The little museum was interesting - our guide explained about the musical instruments and tribal culture and then you go to see the pool which is still considered sacred by the locals. I would question the taking of tourist pictures with the crocs on the bank and suspect that the creatures are doped up in some way to make them docile and allow people to get up close to them. There were hordes of people milling around when we were there which seemed a little surreal. Worth seeing for the experience but like I say, I do question the photo taking......

reviews.title: Well worth a morning or afternoons visit
reviews.text: We had an amazing and extremely knowledgeable guide who's name I'm ashamed to say has completely escaped me. He gave us a wonderful insight into the area's history including the part many of them played during the war for the allies as well as the tribal history of the area. The crocodile park itself is amazing, your literally a few feet from them and if you work with the guides you can actually touch them. Was a shame to see a few tourists not abiding by the guides requests/rules and putting themselves into dangerous situations so please listen to the guides as they are experts with these animals and are extremely aware of keeping them safe too. Make sure you take a bag of lollipops for the local kids too

reviews.title: Trip
reviews.text: Well worth a visit. Guide there takes you through a bit of a history of Gambia some interesting items on show.

reviews.title: Många västafrikanska krokodiler.
reviews.text: Inte europeisk klass på djurpark. Lite obehagligt att inte krokodilerna var inhägnade utan låg lösa framför fötterna på en.

reviews.title: Krokodiili mesta
reviews.text:
Bakaussa lähellä Cape Point-ia sijaitsevassa rokotiilipuistossa n. 100 krokoa. Ennen puistoa pieni museo joka kertoo suppeasti Gambian historiaa. Epäusko valtaa kulkijan lähestyttäessä puistoa, koska tiet ja talot ovat aivan kuin slummia.  Tien päässä on kuitenkin kylläisiä krokoja ja niitä voi taputella jos uskaltaa. Ei hinnalla pilattu jos ei ole ennen krokoja koskenut. Kannattaa ottaa autokuljetus puistolle, n. 5 eskoo per nenä. 
Lazy crocodiles and small museum about Gambia history.

reviews.title: Rør ved en krokodille.
reviews.text: Gik hen til krokodille parken med local guide. The price is 100 krokodiller på stedet. De gik fried rundt mellem os. Vi klappede en af dem (ca. 2 meter lang) på ryggen og løftede på dens bagben. Det skal prøves. Kun 50 kr. I enter.

reviews.title: Very cool!!
reviews.text: Amazing experience! Never thought I would ever touch a crocodile! They are very relaxed and don't mind people being around. Great value for money

reviews.title: Touching Crocodiles
reviews.text:
I visited cricodile pool with Black and White tours. There is a little museum which has intetesting history relating to Gambia and tribal culture. The pool itself is fenced off but the crocodiles are together by pool. There are guides based there for different languages. They let you touch crocodiles but dont touch the crocodiles heads. My guide from Black and White took great pictures.
You can buy real crocodile teeth.
An amazing place to visit

reviews.title: Enjoyed
reviews.text: Been here a few times when in Gambia with my children. They love it. You get up close with the crocodiles as they move about or lay there resting after being fed on fish. You can see them in the crocodile pool swimming by. Before you get to the crocodiles there is a very interesting museum with history of The Gambia and it's men who contributed to the war for England. A place with traditional musical instruments and another room with cultural jujus. The guides are very good and will take you for photos with the crocodiles. I would recommend a visit here when visiting The Gambia.

reviews.title: 6 in 1 tour
reviews.text: There's probably a few travel operators providing this tour and there's certainly plenty of locals offering a taxi style trip. But mine was booked through our Gambia experience rep and included the crocodile pond and museum tour. These fish eating crocodiles! once fed are quite content to bask in the shade while tourists mingle with them and touch their bodies. It's quite surreal and has a complete disregard for eleven n safety or so it appears. The museum is small and informative on the history and culture of the country. Other stops include markets and a tea and coffee stop at a waterside lodge and a traditional wrestling match which was fun. A beach stop to a very pretty beach was some drive and a decent lunch provided. The last stop to a fishing village was canceled due to time. Travel was in an open top bedford lorry which was also fun, generally a good experience despite a little expensive.

reviews.title: Kesyjä krokotiilejä
reviews.text: Hotellilta piti ottaa opas mukaan. 5€ per henkilö. Opas osti lapsille karkkia ja jakoi sitä matkalla. Sisäänpääsy lippu oli oikeasti 100 dalasia eli 2€, sen opas osti. Historia on ilmeisesti gambialaisille tärkeä, koska joka museossa kerrottaisiin vaikka kuinka kauan joka kuvasta jne, museon läpi mennään alueelle. Alue on aika pieni, viidakkomainen polku, muutama iso puu ja sitten krokoja silittelemään. Todella laiskoja krokoja, eivät juurikaan liiku. Ei mikään huippu nähtävyys. Saa aikaa kulumaan lomasta pari tuntia ja 5 eurolla höpötystä joka puusta ja talosta.

reviews.title: Walking among live crocodiles
reviews.text: This hidden park is a photogenic gem. The pond is home to around 100 crocodiles. Behind the pond, you can pet the resident crocodiles, but be sure to ask the staff first. You don't get this close very often.

reviews.title: super atrakcja dotknąć 2m krokodyla
reviews.text: Super atrakcja. Byliśmy w Bakau dzięki miejscowemu przewodnikowi Kincie dotarliśmy tam na piechotę poprzez labirynt delikatnie to nazywając skromnych zabudowań więc jeśli chodzi o zapach krokodyli to dobrze pachną. Obserwacja i dotykanie tych zwierząt było niesamowite i niezapomniane. Nasz przewodnik doskonale się sprawdził byliśmy z nim jeszcze w Monkey Park, na karmieniu sępów i na safarii w Fathala. Jeśli ktoś chciałby skorzystać to +2207796258 kontakt przez whatsapp - tak to tam działa :)

reviews.title: Petting a crocodile
reviews.text: Touching a crocodile for the first time was very impressive. There were over 20 crocodiles in the pond and on the paths.

reviews.title: Good
reviews.text: Worth a visit but not exceptional. They request a donation for food for the crocs! You can have your pic taken whilst touching them

reviews.title: Truly amazing
reviews.text: This is a magnificent place that I have been to 3 times. There is an interesting museum documenting a lot of history. Then you go to the pool and there are over 100 crocs just basking in the sun. You can stroke them. Some people just lark about which is really pathetic as these are wild animals. Well fed on fish but still not to be messed with. Some fools think they are Crocodile Dundee and naturally the guides tell those people off. The crocs seemed happy enough to me. It is a marvellous place and I will go back many times

reviews.title: Mysigt
reviews.text: Liten krokodilpark, men en underbar upplevelse att vara så nära och även kunna klappa dessa varelser.

reviews.title: What a great place to visit
reviews.text: We were given a tour by the men who look after the crocodiles and what a great team they are showing you all the hiding places that the crocodiles use. A must visit if you are in Gambia.

reviews.title: Sömniga krokodiler
reviews.text:
Ett hundratal (!?) mer eller mindre sovande krokodiler... 
Visade inget som helst intresse för någotn eller någon.
Turisterna kunde klappa i stort sett obehindrat.

reviews.title: Poor crocs and agressive guides
reviews.text: Not much to see. Just poor crocs, have no idea how they poison them to keep that calm. Entrance is 100 D, which is ok. But then the so called "guides" will force you to take them for the tips that are 300-400 D (absolutely for nothing). And if you refuse, they gets very agressive and start shouting, including racist abuse. So don"t make them happy, skip this place.

reviews.title: Doing the place up nicely
reviews.text: Went to see the crocodiles today with my family, the museum has had work done to it to make it much better for the public and also the crocodile place was having work done to it too. The tour guy was amazing who walked us round and supported us to touch the crocs. What an amazing experience this was thanks so much to everyone who was part of this.

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text:
This place is good value for money, as a small museum is also on site.
I would advise you have a taxi or take an official tour to get there as it is located in the middle of a busy local area and may be difficult to find as there is not much in the way of signage!

reviews.title: Sacred crocodile pond
reviews.text: The Crocodile Pool has been located in Katchikally for over 500 years. It's a place of pilgrimage; many people believe the animals are sacred and can aid fertility. Many women bathe in the crocodile water. Incidentally, the animals have been tamed, and some are even pettable.

reviews.title: Exciting
reviews.text: You'll walk right through the crocodiles with the guide; they're fed daily so they don't go hungry. Quite a unique experience.

reviews.title: Nice
