reviews.text: For a very small fee, you'll get a thorough explanation and can pet the crocodiles. If you want to see them being fed, it's best to go around 4 p.m.

reviews.title: Wild Crocodiles you can touch
reviews.text: The town of Bakau, just 12 km from Banjul, the capital of The Gambia, hosts an interesting site. A pool with crocodiles, which inexplicably allow themselves to be touched and petted. The pool is named Kachikally (also Katchically or Katchikali) and belongs to the Bojang family which has been administering it for 500ish years. The site is promoted to be a sacred pool in which barren women can bath to wash away whatever has been holding them back from conceiving. After performing the sacred ritual bathing, she is told to remain faithful to her husband and not to shake hands with other men for a year. Faithfully adherent should bring her a child. Required elements of the ritual includes bringing “a humble petition” of “Kola-nuts and other small offerings” to the Bojang family. Entering, I was met by a guide who collected my entrance fee and led me about a hundred yards to the pool (after I suggested that I would visit the museum at the entrance at the end of my visit). The pool and its surrounds are a kind of oasis in the middle of the town. The approximately 9 acre site is surrounded by trees and swamp-like growth and you quickly forget that you are in the middle of a populous town. Right in front of the pool lie the main attractions, 2 meter long crocodiles sunning themselves with their mouths wide open (which is their way of keeping cool). I was the only visitor at the time, but it was starting to see several guides seated just 8-10 feet from these reptiles which strike such fear in southern US States and which generate headlines when their encounters go horribly bad for locals (and often their pets) caught by surprise. I took a step closer, and then another one. Then there I was, bending over and petting a live crocodile, smiling at the camera as my guide took my picture. As I said, I can't explain why I became complacent. It just seemed perfectly natural to wander around the crocodiles, touching them, asking questions, and staring into their gaping, tooth filled mouths. Their semi-catatonic state made me think that perhaps they were sleeping (though their eyes were open and eerily followed you as you moved around). I asked my guide about this, and he smiled again (in fact, I think he never quit smiling). He asked me to get my video camera ready. He said that they were always alert, and ready to pounce on food to which they would be alerted based on the vibration it would make when it hit the ground. Sure enough, he tossed a stick, and as you can see in the video in my blog, they jumped when it hit the ground, and only stopped when its smell didn't register as food. I have more information about Kachikally in my blog, including a list of reasons you may want to visit and a video of how active the crocodiles are. The link is in my profile.

reviews.title: Lifted the crocodile's legs
reviews.text: Health and Safety in Europe wouldn't let you do half the things you can do here. Pose for a photo cuddling a crocodile, lift up its legs & tail - amazing.

reviews.title: Crocs
reviews.text: I pop for a visit to see the crocodiles each time  in the area ... where else could you do this ?! Defiantly worth a visit , maybe not small children 😕

reviews.title: Crocodile pool
reviews.text: Place, where you can see crocodiles very close. You are in the same area with the crocodiles. It is little bit scary to be in the same area with crocodiles. They move very fast but Charlie is one of the croc, which you can touch and be with him in the same picture. You can touch him behind and one of the worker is very close. They give lots of fish for crocs and that's why they are full and satisfied.

reviews.title: Very good experience
reviews.text: Very good experience. The park is not very big but is well maintained. It is possible to get up close to the crocodiles, always under the supervision of the eco-guards. There is also a very interesting museum on several elements of Gambia's history. It is not the main attraction but it is worth a visit.

reviews.title: great place to stroke a croc
reviews.text: I am known for having accidents so my partner was a little apprehensive about going here and allowing me to stroke a croc....what was he worried about? The park is not that big so easy to walk around and there are a few crocs in the main lake you go to < they get one to come out and allow you up close to stroke it> definitely an experience

reviews.title: Croc park
reviews.text: My son and I were apprehensive despite being told that the crocodiles were tame owing to the fact that they are well fed. Nevertheless, the staff were reassuring and lovely. It was a great experience which my son and I thoroughly enjoyed.

reviews.title: Extraordinary place to see crocs
reviews.text: I brought 2 groups here and they were both really excited to see the crocs in and around the pool. The price has been increased dramatically and the managers are in danger of pricing tourists out of here. The museum is interesting but dated in presentation and rather dusty. Visitors who haven't seen crocs before are invariably impressed with the pool. A must see if you visit Gambia.

reviews.title: Amazing to see them up close
reviews.text: Off the beaten track and through a very poor area in Bakou, you get to see a more real side of Gambia on your journey there. There are dozens of crocs here, most of them down in the pond which is fenced off so you can look down without fear of them approaching or you falling in... There are also 1 or 2 up at the top where the guides allow you to go to close to them and take pictures as well as touch them. Crocs are fed a lot of food on the morning so they are not interested in attacking (or even moving), hence the guides assuring you of your safety (They aren't drugged despite the bad reviews) Definitely worth a visit with a tourist taxi rather than a big group, there were less than 10 people there when we visited, well worth spending an hour or so there

reviews.title: Possibly most unnerving experience ever....
reviews.text:
But really glad we did this. 

Go with a local guide. There’s a nice museum at the entrance and a local guide will give you a real flavour of history here and talk about their own tribal histories and customs. 

The walk to the pool itself is interesting - very old tree as well as flora and fauna. 

You suddenly come upon the crocodiles and the first thought is “oh that’s a realistic model” and then you realise the croc next to your foot is alive....

The crocodile keepers are excellent and touching a live croc was something I won’t forget. Which is good because I’m not doing it again either!

This was a real highlight. The animals are well cared for and are not drugged or mistreated. Definitely something to do whilst visiting locally.

reviews.title: dazed crocs
reviews.text: this is just a small park with crocodiles that look like they are drugged. they don't even hardly move and you can touch them.

reviews.title: Interesting and a little scary
reviews.text:
Before you enter to the crocodiles zone, you can visit a good museum showing a bit of Gambia's history, and an exhibition of musical instruments and traditional artifacts, it already starts good.
When you leave the museum, you will be located on the surroundings of a natural pool full of crocodiles, some of them resting around, or directly on your path! the guides know them all (at least this is how it looks) and they tell you which ones are dangerous and which are not, even those that you can touch and how to do it.
Maybe they shouldn't be selling souvenirs with crocodiles teeth, it's the only drawback for this attraction, however, I don't think that they kill them for that.

reviews.title: Museum and crocodile park
reviews.text:
Great little museum, lots of local information, ceremonial masks,instruments.. Was kind if disappointing so short but, worth it.. 
Crocodile park definitely needs investing but, if you can block that thought, its a nice little park.. Guide had lots of information not just about crocs, also fauna and wildlife..able to get close and take pictures guide very patient!!
Nice afternoon out..

reviews.title: Fun and exciting outing
reviews.text: We took this tour, and it's highly recommended for adventurers. You see how the crocodiles live and how they're fed. You can touch and pet them. There's even one (perhaps more) walking around with a missing leg because someone else bit it off in a fight. Our kids and we thought this was a really fun and adventurous excursion. Highly recommended!

reviews.title: Crocs & A Lesson on The Gambia
reviews.text:
Yes you get to see crocodiles. Lots of them. You get to touch a few of them as well. Quite an experience.

What I feel should be mentioned is the little tour of the history of The Gambia as well as the people that you walk through efore getting to the crocs. Its well worth it to get someone knowledgable to take you through the little museum they have there.

No doubt the crocs are the main attraction but why not get a history lesson as well?

I think we paid D100 as an entrance fee. You'd be mad to pass up on this!

reviews.title: Great experience and well worth a visit.
reviews.text:
Small park area with a central pool containing circa 100 crocodiles. The guides claim they only eat fish and don't touch meat but he wasn't prepared to take the £100 on offer to prove it by swimming across.
The opportunity to get up close and actually touch a crocodile. They do seem very tame but no doubt can 'turn' at any time so be careful. 
There's supposed to be a large albino croc called Charlie present but we didn't get to see him as he only appears at feeding time they say.
Lots of little crocs around out of the pool just basking in the sun. Don't walk off the beaten track though as you could easily stumble upon a nest of eggs with the mother watching over them. There's also a few snakes around so perhaps put on some long trousers for protection.
Small entry fee of 100 Gambian Dalasi (around £1.50)
Nice little museum at the entrance charting some of the history of the area and the influence of the British under colonial rule.

reviews.title: Museum and lots of crocodiles
reviews.text: This was our second time here. The museum provides a wealth of information about Gambian history and culture. More than 100 crocodiles can be found in and around the crocodile pool. They remain magnificent creatures, but there are a great many of them living in this "sanctuary."

reviews.title: Fun
reviews.text:
The little museum at the entrance is very interesting and it was great to see all the crocodiles at the pool.  

It was recommended we visit late afternoon, glad we took that advice as we got to see so many of them!!

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text: wow wow wow loved this . Can’t believe we touched a croc. Amazing and a experience and memory that will last a lifetime

reviews.title: Second visit same awesome experience
reviews.text: So this was my second visit to the crocodile pool, this time I went with my 8 year old daughter, 6 year old nephew, sister and 2 year old niece. It was a 100 dalasi fee for entry for adults while the kids went in free. We started off with the tour of the mini museum then proceeded to the pool where the crocodiles are. You are allowed to touch the crocodiles and definitely pictures are allowed this is with the assistance of a tour guide. You can make voluntary donations that goes towards the feeding of the crocodiles, they are fed only fish. I will say it was yet again a beautiful experience.

reviews.title: Too many crocodiles in too small a space!
reviews.text: The Katchikally Crocodile Pool was a disappointment. More than 100 crocodiles are crammed into a pool that's far too small. The animals on dry land act like a circus attraction, posing with the tourists. Some crocodiles were even in the half-open, stinking sewers. Absolutely not for animal lovers.

reviews.title: 'Holy Crocs'
reviews.text:
We, as a couple, visited the fairly basic crocodile pool while staying at The Kairaba Hotel. One hour should easily do. We had mixed feelings, we had the feeling that the animals were sedated and moreover got a 'Lacoste' touch - say, treating wild and normally voracious animals as pets. 
Optional donations are asked for and I wish to think that at a major part is for croc food. The surroundings give a chance to see how the locals live their lifes. Tip: take a taxi driver 'green' to organise the tour for you.

reviews.title: Great opportunity to pet a croc!
reviews.text: This croc pool is an excellent place for you to experience what it feels like to pet a crocodile! The place offers a nice visit and the guides there are really good. It is said that more than 100 crocs live in the pool, which is quite amazing since the pool isn't that big (but 5 meters deep and has underground cave system). There is also a local museum inside the park area.

reviews.title: Excursion
reviews.text: It's amazing to experience this. Go on a tour with the guys from TOC. Local tour guides are excellent at what they do! A real plus for these people.

reviews.title: quite simply mad
reviews.text:
10-15 crocs 3 feet away and NO fences        MAD . 
The walk down to the pool is a must , check out the shops selling hand crafted wooden animals , and cloths

reviews.title: Katchikally Crocodile Pool ,a must see in the Gambia
reviews.text: Spent a hour or so at the Croc pool today as we looked around the Gambia, well worth a visit to see such prehistoric creatures so close up ,certainly a first for me and the wife stroking a crocodile, interesting little museum attached to the pool so made for a interesting visit ,with a cost of D200 well worth a look.

reviews.title: many crocodiles, none doing very much
reviews.text: I walked over to the Katchikally Crocodile Pool, in Bakau, which is in the middle of the town and not easy to find. There is first a pleasant museum with some masks and information about Gambia in the war. The pool itself is small and has many crocodiles, none doing very much. I stroked one on the back and it didn't seem to mind.

reviews.title: Nära möte med krokodiler
reviews.text: Denna park är ganska enkel men det är en häftig upplevelse att vara så nära krokodiler och till och med få klappa dem, om du vågar! Mycket olikt andra parker kan krokodilerna här röra sig mer eller mindre fritt. Jag har varit här två gånger. You can take a walk at the Sunbeach hotel where you can take a walk where you can take a walk in front of the hotel.

reviews.title: Worth a visit!
reviews.text: I have been to Katchikally numerous times over the years and it is always worth going back to! What a novel thing to say you’ve done on holiday, to shake a crocodile’s hand! Cheap and an interesting place to visit.

reviews.title: Curious visit.
reviews.text: When my guide told me we were visiting a museum with crocodiles, I had no idea these animals would be walking around the grounds, within arm's reach (or you within arm's reach). The museum reflects Gambian history, customs, and traditions throughout history with photographs and various exhibits, highlighting the musical instruments, including a kora, large ceremonial drums, and a 1.5-meter-long wooden xylophone. You can see masks and traditional clothing. But the truly spectacular part is seeing the crocodiles found both in the pond and on its banks. The tour is accompanied by a guide who will tell you which crocodile you can touch. After touching it and seeing its motionlessness, I initially thought it was stuffed. When I mentioned this, the guide made it move, and it was truly impressive to see the crocodile with its jaws open so close to me. They explained to me that they are Nile crocodiles and can grow up to four meters long.

reviews.title: Actually very sad
reviews.text: It's a must-see attraction, but it's actually quite sad. There are loads of crocodiles in a small, filthy pool and on the paths. It's not expensive either, 100 dalasi (€1.70), and afterward, a donation is requested to "feed and care for them." The "best" part is actually the ride there. We were by bike, and it takes you through a kind of slum with an open sewer. A good alternative is the small natural pool at Cape Point, Calypso Beach Bar. They're there too, but in a better location.

reviews.title: One to make sure you visit!
reviews.text:
A really good place to visit in The Gambia. 

A lot of history and cultural significance to the area, a really interesting little museum. 

Highlight obviously the pool and touching the crocodiles! 

As always, expect to be asked for ‘a tip’ on top!

reviews.title: worth visiting
reviews.text: Very cheap entrance fee, little museum is good and to be literally stepping over crocodiles and being so close to them is great experience !!!

reviews.title: fasanating
reviews.text: fabulous place with a small museum showing the history of the gambia and the crocodiles are amazing to see and touch.

reviews.title: Great place for children of all ages.....
reviews.text: Allegedly, this sacred pool was established in 1860's or earlier - it is small and a bit grubby but you can get really close to the crocodiles. The small museum and huge trees - you can stand in one - make the whole visit great fun.

reviews.title: Nice trip
reviews.text: I took this trip with Falutours. Individual guidance with a knowledgeable guide. I petted the crocodiles at the crocodile pool. The guide explained everything about the crocodiles and how they came to be.

reviews.title: Quite a small pool with a large number of crocodiles
reviews.text: Called at Katchikally after a visit to Calypso Bar at Cape Point. It is a small pool with a large number of crocodiles in a fairly small area. 200d to enter the site, where there are a number of huts displaying Gambian history before visiting the pool. On reaching the pool a guide approached us and showed us around the pool. The crocodiles are well fed and very docile to the extent that they can be touched

reviews.title: Crocos wild!! :)
reviews.text: We went here with our local guide sonko (sonko1984@yahoo.com) who arranged everything. This place is cheap to go and close. Atmosphere was good, lots of crocos. And first time i had a chance to touch crocodile!! you can donate some money to this place if you want. i Recommend!

reviews.title: Wow!
reviews.text:
An amazing experience and a must-do...to touch a crocodile is a truly fantastic thing and they are not 'crunchy'!!!
Look out for the gigantic 'elephant tree'...it's something else

reviews.title: Very nice
reviews.text: Very nice to do once. Petting crocodiles isn't something you do every day :) Friendly guides are walking around.

reviews.title: Not for the scared
reviews.text: Having held a baby croc in Zimbabwe, it was good to touch a full size one and have the photo to prove it, which I failed to do in Zim.

reviews.title: Nice
reviews.text:
We were taken here by our OTG tourist guide. There is a little museum on site followed by Croc pool. Yes, crocs are everywhere and there is also another guide who will speak to you a bit more about this attractions and will take you around the pond and let you touch some of the crocodiles. 

It's pretty cheap to visit, so do make sure you find a time to come here during your holiday.

reviews.title: Interesting visit to Kachikali
reviews.text: This is my third time in this country. I love Gambia, its people, and everything there is to see. Kachikali Lagoon, a sacred place, is a great place to visit. Being next to crocodiles, petting them, and feeding them fish is very interesting. Walking around and taking a few photos is definitely worth it. At the entrance, there's a mini museum with costumes and photos that gives us a glimpse into the past life of these people. I highly recommend it.

reviews.title: Short but powerful
reviews.text: It's worth the effort, whether you want to or not. You'll get to touch a crocodile, which is quite a thrill. You won't be inside for more than an hour.

reviews.title: Amazing
reviews.text: It's only a small place but well worth the visit, the crocodiles were so calm! The guide was very knowledgeable and you were able to be able to touch the crocodiles which was pretty amazing. For the price you pay you wouldn't get this experience in England!

reviews.title: There be crocodiles
reviews.text: As with most things in Gambia this attraction is very run down and could do with some cash input, perhaps a bit on the admission fee would help towards that. However the guides were knowledgeable. They even managed to coax the 6 teenagers in our group to touch a crocodile. There is also a small museum on site which gives a bit of an insight into the counties heritage. Overall it is worth a visit

reviews.title: Crocodiles seen
reviews.text: We walked with a local guide from a kiosk across from our hotel (Sun Beach) to the crocodile pool. On the way there, you pass through a very poor neighborhood with open sewers and garbage everywhere. Once you arrive at the park, you first visit the museum. It was interesting, about the history of the park and Gambia as a republic. There are also many handmade musical instruments. Walking through the park, you come to the crocodile pool. There are many crocodiles, and you can even touch one. The guide told us a lot about the park; it seems that women who would like to have a child can wash in a special area with water from the pool. Someone walks around asking if you would like to contribute to the fish they have to buy every day. As long as they're full, they obviously don't eat tourists... On the way back through the neighborhood, whole hordes of children chased us, asking for candy, and people trying to sell you notebooks for the children. It was nice, but not spectacular. Another tip: apply DEET. Because of all the water, there are mosquitoes.

reviews.title: nice to see
reviews.text: Petting a crocodile isn't something you get every day, so if you get the chance, you should. A visit to this pool is included in many excursions. P.S.: book your excursions with a local guide: there are plenty of them online with the necessary permits. This way, you support the local population and your visit is much more personal than with a large Tui or Corendon bus.

reviews.title: Touching crocodiles
reviews.text: A must-do if you're in Gambia. You'll have the chance to touch a crocodile. An experience you won't easily have in Europe.

reviews.title: Great place to get up close to crocodiles
reviews.text: it is amazing to get up close and touch the crocodiles. The entrance fee could be a bit higher so that the guides can get their salary and the crocodiles their fish. You then know what you pay for and there is no need to harass visitors about donations and tips.

reviews.title: Krokotiilejä ja historiaa
reviews.text: Pääsimme aluksi museoon, jossa oma paikallinen oppaamme kertoi hyvin mielenkiintoisia asioita Gambian historiasta, riiteistä ja heimoista sekä lähihistoriasta. Tämän jälkeen katsomaan krokotiilejä, mitä lapset odottivat. Krokotiilejä oli lampi täynnä ja niitä pääsi silittämään ystävällisen oppaan avustuksella. Varaa tännekin hieman ylimääräistä koska myös täällä kysellään lahjoitusta puistolle.

reviews.title: Great place to visit
reviews.text:
We were very interested to see and touch the crocodiles at Katchikally crocodile pool and hear about the history and beliefs of the local people. 
Touching a crocodile has to be a bucket list things to do & we were not disappointed. our guide explained how the crocs are cared for and fed and it was a very interesting trip.

reviews.title: Crocodile Pool
reviews.text: A fun outing. The museum wasn't as interesting, but the Crocodile Pool was definitely worth it! It was so much fun to see them up close and even touch them!

reviews.title: The one who dances with the crocodile...
reviews.text: The crocodiles in the pool are certainly worth seeing. They aren't particularly large, but that may be due to the fact that they're fed exclusively with fish. At the entrance, there's a small museum with numerous exhibits and photographs. Then, you walk a few steps to the small lake where the crocodiles frolic. The small circular path is romantic and lined with some ancient trees.

reviews.title: Make friends with the crocks
reviews.text: Waw! It was a very exciting experience visiting this very historic place in my own home town. The crocks are said to be sacred and believed to have healing powers.Good place to mingle and touch the crocks. The staff are very friendly and gives good info about the place.

reviews.title: Perfect for cocktails at sunset
reviews.text: Enjoy dinner, drinks or a snack next to the crocodile pool watching the birds swooping down to drink

reviews.title: Spännande utflykt
reviews.text: Mycket pulshöjande utflykt med lösa krokodiler spatserande! De är ju dock matade och mätta och inte människoätare. Men who want to know what they are doing is a man inside the trampar not before 190 krokodilerna på svansen😳 Du får även chansen att klappa en livs levande krokodil! Sonen på 10 år var den som var tuffast i vårat sällskap 👍🏻

reviews.title: Worth a look
reviews.text: Museum rooms are interesting, plenty of crocs to See, you can get up close and personal if you wish!!

reviews.title: Exciting
reviews.text: Fancy petting a crocodile? Make sure a park guide is with you! There's also a painter at the park exit who creates beautiful African paintings.

reviews.title: Spännande
reviews.text: Man går inne i parken där de har lösa krokodiler, känns ganska säkert, för de matar dem rejält på morgonen 🤔

reviews.title: Worth a visit
reviews.text: We visited this as a family, the museum is really interesting but small; it gives an insight to the history of the country including war and politics. The croc pool is okay, not sure how much I believe about them not chasing us cos they only eat fish.

reviews.title: Another nice trip with Lamin our taxi driver
reviews.text: We visited Bakau, Gambia, in January 2018. Our taxi driver and guide also took us to the Crocodile Pool. It was another enjoyable excursion, especially the ride from the hotel to the pool. If you're looking for a good and reliable taxi driver, Lamin is a good choice. With his permission, I was allowed to share his phone number. You can reach him via WhatsApp at 002209822596. He drives smoothly and is very familiar with the area. He knows many people and charges a fair price. Highly recommended.

reviews.title: Beautiful myth
reviews.text: The story behind the crocodile pond is a beautiful myth. It's unbelievable to see so many crocodiles together. The experience really depends on the guide you have, I think. We had a really nice one, Moses, who really enjoyed his work. I also really enjoyed feeding the crocodile fish. Not a must-see, but definitely worth it.

reviews.title: Up close and personal to crocodiles
reviews.text:
Crocodile pool - it's not everyday that you can get to stroke a crocodile but here you can.entrance fee is very cheap and as you walk through the museum you get a sense of history with all the artifacts and pictures on show,you then meander through the gardens hearing and seeing different birds until you come to the croc pool.a guide will go with you explaining about the origins of the pool(used for fertility rites) and take you to stroke crocodiles and will gladly take photos for you.
Excellent way to spend a couple of hours

reviews.title: Nice!
reviews.text: We cycled there from Kotu. My children thought it was exciting to see it for themselves. You can easily walk among the crocodiles, and with a good guide, the museum is also fun to visit. You'll hear the stories behind them.

reviews.title: Mixed Feelings!!
reviews.text: My wife and I visited this crocodile pool while staying at the Senegambia Beach Hotel. I have mixed feelings. Although it was a great place to visit, I couldn't help but feel that some of the animals were sedated. It just don't seem right a load of people being able to go and touch a crocodile, but again, having said this it was also a fantastic experience to do such a thing. They do ask for a donation, although this is optional. I would like to think that at least half of the donation is put towards the crocs food. The surrounding area is a bit of an eye-opener, but do give you the chance to see up close how the not so fortunate locals actually live. It is worth going for the experience and close up site of these amazing creatures up close, just remain a bit open-minded by the experience. Tip If you are staying in or near the Senegambia Beach Hotel, get 'Del-Boy' to organize the tour for you. Well organized and worth the money. He is always down on the beach.

reviews.title: Fun to do with local taxi
reviews.text: We went there with Bamba. If you take a local taxi, they'll also accompany you and can tell you a lot about the park. Bamba also has a Facebook page: bamba taxi gambia

reviews.title: Great!
reviews.text: Definitely worth a visit amazing to sit by the mangrove whilst seeing the sea in the distance. Lovely drinks and food.

reviews.title: Beautiful experience
reviews.text: Our guide, Bob, took us here. We first walked through the compounds to get a feel for the community and how the people live. This is definitely recommended to make a visit to the crocodile pool even more enjoyable. The crocodiles live very peacefully, are fed daily, and are almost all tame.

reviews.title: Crocodiles up close
reviews.text: Katchikally Crocodile is easy to find, once in Bakau you only have to ask and you will be given directions, there is no need to join a your group. Don’t get fooled into signing a donation book near the entrance. Pay the entrance fee at the gate and walk around the pool / lake amongst the crocodiles, the crocs are well fed and take no notice of the tourists walking and standing next to them.

reviews.title: Nice
reviews.text: It's a fun thing to do in a morning. You can get a great photo with crocodiles. We walked there from Cape Point. It's easy, but check Google Maps first to see where you need to be.

reviews.title: Something to do in Gambia
reviews.text:
Difficult to rate:

Before getting to the crocodile pool, there is a museum - 5 little huts: very interesting and informative. 
The crocodile pool is ok, lot of crocodile and there's a keeper that talks about the place. You can get up close to the crocodiles. You are allowed to touch the crocodile. Not sure if that is normal. The keeper said they feed them the night before so they are not hungry when tourist are around. 

The keeper will ask you to donate money to feed the crocodile. I wish I said No because you pay an entrance fee. I gave equivalent of less than $1 so that. 

The most uncomfortable part of this visit was the children at the entrance aggressively begging for money with directions/encouragement from their mothers.

reviews.title: Of two minds this is animal exploitation...
reviews.text: Conveniently placed for a quick trip from the hotel area and it is not a big attraction. Being an anti-city zoo, anti-circus type family this is NOT wild reptiles in a natural environment what ever the low price. And getting young children to bonk a maybe unhappy creature on the head is not setting a good example for future conduct with Africa wildlife. Anyway they enjoyed the experience, pool men could be better informed and interactive in the job role. Information center was useful.

reviews.title: Difficult to rate
reviews.text:
Our todler had the best time at the crocodile pool. He really like petting the crocodiles. Kept talking about it all week.
But... this is not natural and in hindsight we should have never participated in this type of animal abuse. 
The adjacent museum is quite informative and we found it a pleasant surprise at this crocodile site.

reviews.title: One of the highlights of our trip
reviews.text: Crocodiles galore and you're even able to touch one if you dare! Fabulous to see so many together and all for 100 dalasi (less than £2), over a hundred in and around the pool.

reviews.title: Well worth a visit...
reviews.text: We visited at new year 2018.  Had been here 31 years ago!  It is a small area...the crocks are cute and the little history museum is an interesting and useful addition.  You can (should) walk to it from the Cape Point hotels.

reviews.title: Krokodiler överallt
reviews.text: Jag tyckte det var rätt obehagligt att besöka Crocodile Pool men det var ingen fara även fast det låg krokodiler precis överallt. Du får klappa dom och riktigt ta del av krokodilernas på nära håll.

reviews.title: small but nice
reviews.text: For 100 dhalasi, it's a fun attraction. The exhibition beforehand isn't much to look at. There are, however, a lot of crocodiles in a small pool.

reviews.title: Feeding the crocs
reviews.text: This is a place to visit. The crocs are lovely warm creatures and there is always a keeper there. I actually fed them and stroked one. It's a must for animal lovers.

reviews.title: petting a crocodile...
reviews.text: First, you'll explore the history of Gambia (museum), then you'll visit a crocodile pool. I warned you yesterday, because they're still wild animals! But you'll get the chance to touch/pet a crocodile. It's fun, yet a little bit exciting!

reviews.title: Scary
reviews.text:
Having grown up in Malawi and Zimbabwe found it quite scary watching my children touching a crocodile. 

Excellent activity for a family.

reviews.title: To touch a crocodile
reviews.text: You want to get as close as you have ever been to a crocodile. This is ideal. Not sure about the health and safety side of things but worth a vist. Don't expect too much it is fairly basic.

reviews.title: Aggressive guides
reviews.text: When we refused to talk to and shake hands with some annoying "guides" there, we were called racists. It is interesting to have a possibility to get in contact with crocodiles, I recommend this place for this opportunity, but beware of the "guides" at the pool

reviews.title: Good value experience
reviews.text:
Entrance was only 100 dalasi so good value. There's a museum on site, but I personally just wanted to touch a crocodile! Wasn't disappointed, there's looots of them in a small pool, lying around everywhere, calm and lazy just lounging. 
Nice place to spend part of your day - won't take more than an hour of your time!

reviews.title: An interesting excursion, but don't expect too much!
reviews.text: Katchikally is one of those 'must see it' excursions that are thrust upon every visitor to the Gambia and, to be fair, it is an interesting way to spend an hour or two. Just don't expect a major tourist attraction - and we didn't find any toilets! Quite simply, this is a rather muddy pool surrounded by trees and occupied by an assortment of tame crocodiles that do very little. It is apparently used for fertility rituals and is owned by one of the wealthiest families in Gambia Yes, you can touch the crocodiles if you feel brave. You will be surrounded by other visitors most of the time and the 'keepers' will try (insistently) to sell you handmade crocodile teeth necklaces and other overpriced craft items. I was slightly perturbed by the keeper's insistence that we should give him a 'donation' to pay for the crocodile's fish, especially as we had just paid to get in. Was this official or just another Bumster trick? I suspect the latter! The best bit for me was the small museum at the venue's entrance. There are some interesting examples of local drums and musical instruments with some ceremonial costumes. I was particularly fascinated by the display of old photographs. For me, this was worth the entrance fee on its own. In short, Katchikally is a tourist trap, but a relatively gentle one. The crocodile custodians are generally pleasant and you will almost certainly enjoy your visit.

reviews.title: Nothing spectacular
reviews.text: Ok but wouldn't travel a distance to visit. Journey through back streets seeing how locals live was more interesting.

reviews.title: If you're in the area anyway...
reviews.text: A pond with crocodiles and a museum of local history. That's it. Most tourists get there accompanied by a taxi driver who also acts as a guide.

reviews.title: Great adventure
reviews.text: Amazing time, great guide to help us through the crocodile pools, keep an eye out as there is wildlife everywhere.

reviews.title: Pieni alue, jossa nähtävää korkeintaan tunniksi
reviews.text: Aluksi oma oppaamme vei meidät kiertämään paikan museon, jossa oli mielenkiintoisia esineitä Gambian historiasta, kulttuurista, musiikista, perinteistä jne. Siellä olisi viettänyt enemmänkin aikaa. Sitten menimme krokotiilialtaalle, jossa kierroksen hoiti paikan oma opas. Krokotiilit oli aamulla syötetty, ja siinä niitä lepäsi toistakymmentä auringossa. Oppaan johdolla niitä sai koskea ja silittää, mikä oli ihan jännittävää. Charlieta, isointa ja vanhinta krokotiilia emme nähneet, oli kuulemma jossain lammikon keskellä veden alla todennäköisesti. Kierroksen lopuksi toki sitten pyydettiin "vapaaehtoista" lahjoitusta paikan toimintaa tukemaan. Monessa kohtaa näki, että turisti oli esim. antanut 100 dalasia, mutta summaa oli jälkikäteen korjailtu ylöspäin. Ovelasti luotiin ryhmäpainetta lahjoittaa isompi summa?

reviews.title: Go when it’s quiet
reviews.text: We were they only ones there ( apart from the guides) was very quiet and calm...there are literally 100 plus crocodiles, by your feet, no bands round their mouths, no obvious protection.  I thought it would be naff, thoroughly enjoyed it!!

reviews.title: Snappy Happy Crocs
reviews.text: Quite a small park where you will walk around a pool populated by crocodiles.Dens align the sides of the pool with baby crocs and mothers.They are well fed and looked after.

reviews.title: Crocs everywhere!
reviews.text: A gentle tour round the small museum, then on to see and touch the crocs. Was it scary - yes! However, we felt very safe with our guide and the Croc Pool staff.

reviews.title: A must do if you are in the area!
reviews.text: From the hotel in Cape Point, we walked there on our own, without a guide. Google Maps points the way perfectly. It's an experience in itself. Admission is 100 dalasi per person. We walk through five round davels, which serve as a museum with a wealth of information about the country's history. Along a sandy path, we pass the old tree where circumcisions were once performed. Just before the pool, we're met by a guide who explains the use and significance of the sacred site. He took a few photos of us petting the crocodiles—it was fun! At the end, we gave the guide 100 dalasi for the explanation.

reviews.title: A place to visit
reviews.text:
A  nice walk through a forest/jungle with lots to see, and then there's t
lots of crocodiles in ponds and walking around. You actually not very far from them

reviews.title: Very cool
reviews.text: The people running it were easy going and friendly - we enjoyed our visit! I even picked up a crocs tail!

reviews.title: Great to experience
reviews.text: We went there with a local guide and a local taxi driver. There's a fun museum with all sorts of explanations and artifacts from the Gambian people. Then you walk through a forest with a very old tree to a pond where crocodiles are scattered. You can touch them, feed them fish, and take photos and videos. I don't get the impression that the animals are being abused.

reviews.title: Dundee
reviews.text:
Went through the museum at the beginning where your shown a bit of the history of the Gambian people going all the way back to their magical beliefs up to when the queen visited and also the recruiting of troops from Gambia in the Second World War 

The crocodile pool is pretty good they’ll be couple out the water where they’ll be a chance to have your photo taken with the crocs. They’ll also explain about the spiritual beliefs of the pool. 

On the whole not a bad bit of money spent buy don’t get prepared to be blown away

reviews.title: A crocodile petting zoo with local heritage museum
reviews.text:
We’ve been here early October before high Season (Oct 15th-Dec)

It’s a small place best visited out of season. The guides have time to show you around and tell something about the crocs.

If you take of one of the locals to take you there you can stay away from the tourist traffic days. I wouldn’t wanna be there when there’s a group of 20-30 tourist that just got there.

That said, it’s good fun and a good thrill. Even though they’re well fed with fish, it’s still an exciting event to be able to touch them and feel the skin of these prehistoric survivors.

Entrance fee is about 100 dalasi.

This includes the museum with some of the festive and traditional clothing, music instruments and the juju (voodoo) department.

reviews.title: Snappy!
reviews.text: We had a great time here. The museum first of all was insightful, learning about local tribes and their tools of trade. Then through to see the crocs. There were a lot of crocs so everyone could take turns in stroking them. The keepers would tell you which ones to stay away from and which ones to touch. They were on the ball and made sure everyone was safe. Even my children got to touch them. Great place to visit.

reviews.title: Crocodile pool in a very poor neighborhood.
reviews.text: We visited the crocodile with a local guide. He did not know the location exactly so we stranded a few hundred meters from the entrance. The road are terrible and if you have to walk you realize you walking along open sewer. First thing to visit is the museum that gives a good impression of the area in the old days. When you walk along you will find the crocodiles that have been fed already so you are able to touch them. Around the pool it is relative clean but the garbage has been thrown into the behind the trees it looks like a garbage disposal area. Still touching the crocodiles is a special experience.

reviews.title: Excursions With local guide Yaya Mannah
reviews.text: I'd seen so many crocodiles, and it seemed harmless to touch them. I cautiously did so anyway.

reviews.title: Been able to touch the crocs🙄🙄🙄
reviews.text: Went to see crocs, touched a live croc and it didnt bite me. Believe me cro s were evefywhere liten to the guides an obey what they tell you.

reviews.title: A unique experience - MUST visit place
reviews.text: This was my second time to Gambia and I couldn't miss to visit this place one more time. Last time it was summer so the pool was not full of water but this time it was raining and the experience was simply amazing. The pool was full of water so could not see the Crocs lying on the side. You enter the park by paying a nominal fee and if lucky find crocodiles walking along with you on the side or may be just lying next to the walking path. They are harmless until she is a female. Female is more into defense to protect her eggs. You reach near the pool and find so many of them just lying over there, may be waiting for you to sit besides them and have your pictures taken. Believe me, it is an amazing experience regardless you like animals or not. These Crocs are never fed meat and they eat almost 3,000 Kg of fish daily (that's what rangers told, not sure how much true it is). Please make sure that the rangers are around and guide you which Croc to be with while taking the pictures. Stay away from the female Crocs. If the water level is a bit low in the pool then you can go close by and see many Crocs walking towards you from the water or the side. There is nothing to worry about but you must need to take precautions while with animals. There is a small shop that sells crocodile tooth and they are not expensive, may be around 150 - 200 dalasis. They also ask for the donation and have maintained a register of donors. They have a nicely maintained museum in the front that depicts many ancient and authentic articles including weapons, cooking vessels, musical instruments etc. There is also a history of Gambia associated with it if you are interested in it. It is a belief of the locals that a lady who is not able to conceive a baby can visit this place and take a dip in the pool to be an expectant mom in the future.

reviews.title: Shocking
reviews.text: It's also interesting to see and touch these animals on a cultural visit, where you can visit their museum and learn about part of this country's history.

reviews.title: Nice and creepy
reviews.text:
A trip to Bakau is more than visiting a crocodile pool. You also see how poor this neighbourhood is. Pretty shocking. Children are happy if you give them something to eat or something small like a ball. 
Bakau pool is completely filled with crocs. You have to see it to believe it. You can touch them ( I' m not a fan). I' ve filmed it for my pupils, they found me an awesome teacher :-)
